On average, close to 300,000 legal immigrants enter the country every year; about half{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} are ethnic Russians from the other republics of the former Soviet Union. There is a significant inflow of ethnic [[Armenians]], [[Uzbeks]], [[Kyrgyz people|Kyrgyz]] and [[Tājik people|Tajiks]] into big Russian cities, something that is viewed unfavorably by some citizens.[http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2007/10/75118827-7d89-462e-b4b5-6a433de19a49.html Central Asia: Labor Migrants Face Abuse, Xenophobia] Rferl.org, Retrieved on 15 March 2008 According to a 2013 opinion poll, 74% of Russians view the large number of labor migrants as a negative phenomenon.{{cite news|first=Alisher|last=Ilkhamov|url=http://www.fairobserver.com/region/europe/central-asian-migrants-russia-heated-debate-69753/|title=Central Asian Migrants in Russia: A Heated Debate|work=Fair Observer|date=March 19, 2014}} According to the [[United Nations]], Russia's legal immigrant population is the third biggest in the world, numbering 11.6 million.{{cite news|first=Ashley|last=Kirk|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/12111108/Mapped-Which-country-has-the-most-immigrants.html|title=Mapped: Which country has the most immigrants?|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=21 Jan 2016}} In addition, there are an [[Illegal immigration in Russia|estimated 4 million illegal immigrants]] from the [[Republics of the Soviet Union|ex-Soviet]] states in Russia.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsru.com/russia/23nov2010/migranty.html |title=Новости NEWSru.com :: ФМС: в РФ нелегально работают 3 млн трудовых мигрантов, остальные 4 млн "халтурят" с налогами |website=Newsru.com |accessdate=14 May 2011}} In 2015, Ukraine-Russia was the world's largest migration corridor after Mexico-USA.{{cite news|url=http://pubdocs.worldbank.org/en/661301460400427908/MigrationandDevelopmentBrief26.pdf#page=7|title=Migration and Remittances: Recent Developments and Outlook|date=April 2016}} According to the Armenian government, between 80,000 and 120,000 Armenians travel to Russia every year to do seasonal work, returning home for the winter.{{cite news|first=Lilit|last=Arakelyan|url=https://iwpr.net/global-voices/armenians-enticed-russian-passport-offer|title=Armenians Enticed by Russian Passport Offer|date=4 June 2014}} According to the Tajik government, at least 870,000 Tajiks are working in Russia.{{cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/a/tajik-official-says-migration-to-russia-down/27873757.html|title=Tajik Official Says Migration To Russia Down|date=July 22, 2016}} In 2014, [[remittance]]s from Russia accounted for around one-third of Kyrgyzstan's and over 40% of Tajikistan's GDP.{{cite news|first=Kanat|last=Shaku|url=http://www.intellinews.com/central-asian-remittances-from-russia-begin-to-recover-107159/|title=Central Asian remittances from Russia begin to recover|date=September 30, 2016}} The [[Kazakhs]] in Russia are mostly not recent immigrants.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} The majority inhabit regions bordering [[Kazakhstan]] such as the [[Astrakhan Oblast|Astrakhan]] (16% of the population are [[Kazakhs]]), [[Orenburg Oblast|Orenburg]] (6% of the population are [[Kazakhs]]), [[Omsk Oblast|Omsk]] (4% of the population are [[Kazakhs]]) and [[Saratov Oblast|Saratov]] (3% of the population are [[Kazakhs]]) oblasts. Together these oblasts host 60% of the Kazakh population in Russia. The number of [[Kazakhs]] slightly decreased between 2002 and 2010 due to emigration to [[Kazakhstan]], which has by far the strongest economy in Central Asia (Russia does receive immigration from Kazakhstan, but they are mainly ethnic Russians); other Central Asian populations, especially Uzbeks, Tajiks, and Kyrgyz, have continued to rise rapidly. (Turkmen are an exception; citizens of Turkmenistan do not have [[visa policy of Russia|visa-free access]] to Russia.) Russian statistical organizations classify the immigrants based on their ethnicity, although there is an information gap between 2007 and 2013, In 2007, the net immigration was 190,397 (plus another 49,546 for which ethnicity was unknown). Of this, 97,813 was Slavic / Germanic / Finnic (51.4%, of which Russian – 72,769, Ukrainian – 17,802), Turkic and other Muslim – 52,536 (27.6%, of which Azeri – 14,084, Tatar – 10,391, Uzbek – 10,517, Tajik – 9,032, Kyrgyz – 7,533 & Kazakh – (-) 1,424) and Others – 40,048 (21.0%, of which Armenian – 25,719).{{cite web|url=http://www.gks.ru/bgd/regl/B08_16/IssWWW.exe/Stg/html1/07-11.htm|title=Национальный состав международных мигрантов|website=Gks.ru|accessdate=21 June 2015}} Many immigrants are actually migrant workers, who come to Russia and work for around five years then return to their countries. Major sources of migrant workers but where permanent migrants of majority ethnicity of those countries are virtually nonexistent are in 2013. [[China]] 200,000 migrant workers, 1000 settled permanently. [[Uzbekistan]] 100,000 migrant workers, 489 permanent settlers. [[Tajikistan]] 80,000 migrant workers, 220 settled permanently. [[Kyrgyzstan]] 50,000 miagrant workers, 219 settled permanently. [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]- 20,000 worker arrivals, 612 settled permanently. {{flagu|Uzbekistan}}: 131,100 {{flagu|Ukraine}}: 93,400 {{flagu|Tajikistan}}: 87,100 {{flagu|Azerbaijan}}: 67,900 {{flagu|Armenia}}: 59,400 {{flagu|Kyrgyzstan}}: 44,600 {{flagu|Moldova}}: 33,900 {{flagu|China}}: 28,400 {{flagu|Kazakhstan}}: 28,100 {{flagu|Belarus}}: 27,700 {{flagu|Georgia}}: 12,100 {{flagu|Vietnam}}: 11,100 {{flagu|Turkmenistan}}: 5,600 {{flagu|Turkey}}: 5,400 {{flagu|Estonia}}, {{flagu|Latvia}}, {{flagu|Lithuania}}: 5,300 {{flagu|India}}: 4,500 All others: 41,400 ===Median age and fertility=== Median ages of ethnic groups vary considerably between groups. Ethnic Russians and other Slavic and Finnic groups have higher median age compared to the Caucasian groups. Median ages are strongly correlated with [[Total fertility rate|fertility rates]], ethnic groups with higher fertility rates have lower median ages, and vice versa. For example, in 2002, in the ethnic group with the lowest median age – [[Ingush people|Ingush]] – women 35 or older had, on average, 4.05 children; in the ethnic group with the highest median age – Jews – women 35 or older averaged only 1.37 children.{{cite web|url=http://www.perepis2002.ru/ct/html/TOM_12_05.htm|title=5. ЖЕНЩИНЫ НАИБОЛЕЕ МНОГОЧИСЛЕННЫХ НАЦИОНАЛЬНОСТЕЙ ПО ВОЗРАСТНЫМ ГРУППАМ И ЧИСЛУ РОЖДЕННЫХ ДЕТЕЙ ПО СУБЪЕКТАМ РОССИЙСКОЙ ФЕДЕРАЦИИ|website=Prerpis2002.ru|accessdate=1 September 2017}} Ethnic Jews have both the highest median age and the lowest fertility rate; this is a consequence of [[Aliyah|Jewish emigration]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}} Ethnic Russians represent a significant deviation from the pattern, with second lowest fertility rate of all major groups, but relatively low median age (37.6 years). This phenomenon is at least partly due to a high mortality rate among older people, especially males as well af the fact that children from mixed marriages are often registered as ethnic Russians in the census. The most noticeable trend in the past couple of decades is the convergence of birth rates between minorities (including Muslim minorities) and the Russian majority.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} The following table shows the variation in median age and fertility rates according to 2002 census.{{cite web|url=http://perepis2002.ru/ct/doc/TOM_04_07.xls|format=XLS|title=7. | Islam |} ==Languages== {{Main|Languages of Russia}} Russian is the common official language throughout Russia understood by 99% of its current inhabitants and widespread in many adjacent areas of Asia and Eastern Europe. National subdivisions of Russia have additional official languages (see their respective articles). There are more than 100 languages spoken in Russia, many of which are [[endangered language|in danger of extinction]]. ==Religion== {{Main|Religion in Russia}} {{Further|Russian Orthodox the [http://sreda.org/arena/maps?mainsection=minust Russian Ministry of Justice (Минюста РФ)]. |label1 =[[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox Christianity]] |value1 = 42.5 |color1 = Orchid |label2 = Unaffiliated [[Christian]]s |value2 = 4.1 |color2 = DodgerBlue |label3 = Other Christians{{efn|Including [[Old Believers]] (0.2%), [[Protestantism]] (0.2%), and [[Catholic Church|Catholicism]] (0.1%).}} |value3 = 0.5 |color3 = Turquoise |label4 = [[Spiritual but not religious]] |value4 = 25 |color4 = WhiteSmoke |label5 = [[Atheism|Atheists]] |value5 = 13 |color5 = Silver |label6 = [[Islam|Muslims]]{{efn|name=ArenaIslam|The Sreda Arena Atlas 2012 did not count the populations of two Muslim-majority federal subjects of Russia, namely [[Chechnya]] and [[Ingushetia]], which together had a population of nearly 2 million, thus the proportion of Muslims may be slightly underestimated.}} |value6 = 6.5 |color6 = Green |label7 = [[Modern Paganism|Pagans]]{{efn|The category included [[Slavic Native Faith|Rodnovers]] accounting for 44%, [[Hinduism|Hinduists]] accounting for 0.1%, and other Pagan religions and Siberian Tengrists and shamans accounting for the rest.}} |value7 = 1.3 |color7 = Chartreuse |label8 = [[Buddhism|Buddhists]] |value8 = 0.5 |color8 = Yellow |label9 = Other religions{{efn|Including [[Judaism]] (0.1%) and other unspecified religions.}} |value9 = 1.1 |color9 = Tomato |label10 = Undeclared |value10 = 5.5 |color10 = Black }} [[File:Temple of Christ the Savior view from Patriarchy Bridge.jpg|thumb|left|200px|[[Cathedral of Christ the Saviour]], Moscow]] Russia officially recognizes Orthodox Christianity, Islam, Judaism, and Buddhism as traditional religions. Russia has large populations of non-practicing believers and non-believers; many people identify only nominally with a religion. There is no official census on religion in Russia. The Pew Research Center found that 71% of Russians identified as Orthodox, with 1.8% Protestants, 0.5% Catholics and 0.3% other Christians.{{cite web|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2011/12/19/table-christian-population-as-percentages-of-total-population-by-country/|title=Christian Population|website=pewforum.org|accessdate=13 April 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2017/05/10/religious-affiliation/|title=Religious Belief and National Belonging in Central and Eastern Europe|website=pewforum.org|accessdate=13 April 2018}} Pew estimated 11.7% of the population to be Muslim as of 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2011/01/27/table-muslim-population-by-country/|title=Muslim Population by Country|website=pewforum.org|accessdate=13 April 2018}} Estimates of practicing worshipers are: Russian Orthodox 15-20%, Muslim 10-15%, other Christian 2% (2006 est.).https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/rs.html Only a small percentage of the population is strongly religious: about approximately 2–4%{{cite web|url=http://www.rusk.ru/st.php?idar=13228 |title=Русская линия / Библиотека периодической печати / Как пишутся страшные сказки о Церкви |website=Rusk.ru |date=31 August 2005 |accessdate=14 May 2011}} of the general population are integrated into church life (воцерковленные), while others attend on a less regular basis or not at all. Many non-religious ethnic Russians identify with the Orthodox faith for cultural reasons.{{cite web|url=http://www.ecsocman.edu.ru/images/pubs/2006/05/04/0000276258/35-Filatovx2c_Lunkin.pdf |language=Russian |title=Социология религии |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5oC7ptCGp?url=http://www.ecsocman.edu.ru/images/pubs/2006/05/04/0000276258/35-Filatovx2c_Lunkin.pdf |archivedate=13 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} The majority of Muslims live in the Volga–Ural region and the [[North Caucasus]], although Moscow, Saint Petersburg, and parts of Siberia also have sizable Muslim populations.{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90196.htm|title=Russia|website=State.gov|accessdate=1 September 2017}}[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/rs.html#People Russia CIA World Factbook] [[CIA World Factbook]] updated 6 March 2008 Other branches of Christianity present in Russia include Roman Catholicism (approx. 1%), [[Baptists]], [[Pentecostals]], [[Lutherans]] and other Protestant churches (together totalling about 0.5% of the population) and [[Old Believers]].[http://sreda.org/en/arena "Arena: Atlas of Religions and Nationalities in Russia"]. Sreda, 2012.[http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg 2012 Arena Atlas Religion Maps]. "Ogonek", № 34 (5243), 27/08/2012. Retrieved 21/04/2017. [https://web.archive.org/web/20170421154615/http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg Archived]. There is some presence of Judaism, [[Buddhism]], [[Hinduism]] and other pagan beliefs are also present to some extent in remote areas, sometimes [[Syncretism|syncretized]] with one of the mainstream religions. According to the data of the 2010 Census, presented above, 88.26% of the people who stated their ethnicity belong to traditional Christian ethnic groups, 10.90% belong to traditional Muslim ethnic groups and 0.84% belong to traditional Buddhist, Jewish, Hindu and other ethnic groups. ==Education== [[File:1 сентября - День знаний !.JPG|thumb|200px|The 1st September, [[Knowledge day]] in Russia]] {{Main|Education in Russia}} ===Literacy=== ''definition:'' age 15 and over can read and write
''total literacy:'' 99.7% (2015)
''male:'' 99.7%
''female:'' 99.6% Russia's free, widespread and in-depth educational system, inherited with almost no changes from the Soviet Union, has produced nearly 100% literacy. 97% of children receive their compulsory 9-year basic or complete 11-year education in Russian. Other languages are also used in their respective republics, for instance [[Tatar language|Tatar]] (1%), [[Yakut language|Yakut]] (0.4%) etc.{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} About 3 million students attend Russia's 519 institutions of higher education and 48 universities. As a result of great emphasis on [[Science, technology and society|science and technology]] in education, Russian medical, mathematical, scientific, and space and aviation research is generally of a high order.{{cite web|url=http://www.eubusiness.com/Russia/russia-country-guide/ |title=Russia country guide – EUbusiness.com – business, legal and financial news and information from the European Union |website=Eubusiness.com |accessdate=14 May 2011}} ==Labour force== The Russian [[labour force]] is undergoing tremendous changes. Although well-educated and skilled, it is largely mismatched to the rapidly changing needs of the [[Russian economy]]. The unemployment rate in Russia was 5.3% as of 2013.{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20131017-705657.html | work=The Wall Street Journal | title=Russia Capital Investment Falls 1.6% in September - Rosstat}} Unemployment is highest among women and young people. Following the [[breakup of the Soviet Union]] and the economic dislocation it engendered, the standard of living fell dramatically. However, since recovering from the [[1998 Russian financial crisis|1998 economic crisis]], the standard of living has been on the rise. As of 2010 about 13.1% of the population was living below the [[list of countries by percentage of population living in poverty|poverty line]], compared to 40% in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.indexmundi.com/russia/population_below_poverty_line.html|title=Russia Population below poverty line|website=Indexmundi.com|accessdate=21 June 2015}} The average yearly salary in Russia was $14,302 (about $23,501 [[purchasing power parity|PPP]]) as of October 2013, up from $455 per year in August 1999.[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/24443419/ Russians weigh an enigma with Putin's protégé] [[MSNBC]] Retrieved on 29 March 2009{{cite web|title=Putin's Economy—Eight Years On|website=Russiaprofile.org|url=http://www.russiaprofile.org/page.php?pageid=Business&articleid=a1187177738|accessdate=27 December 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071222040740/http://www.russiaprofile.org/page.php?pageid=Business&articleid=a1187177738|archivedate=22 December 2007|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NY.GDP.PCAP.PP.CD|title=GDP per capita, PPP (current international $)|website=Data.worldbank.org|accessdate=21 June 2015}} According to the FMS, as of 2011, there were 7,000,000 immigrants working in Russia. Half of these were from Ukraine, while the remainder was mostly from Central Asia. Only 3 million or less than half of all the immigrants are legal. Illegal immigrants number 4 million, mostly from Ukraine and the Caucasus. The Census usually covers only a part of this population and the last one (2002 Census) counted one million non-citizens. ==Population of main cities== Russia is a highly urbanized country, with 74.2% of the total population (2017) living in urban areas. [[Moscow]] is the capital and [[List of cities and towns in Russia by population|most populous city]] of Russia, with 12.2 million residents within the [[city limits]]http://www.gks.ru/free_doc/new_site/population/demo/Popul2015.xls and 17.1 million within the [[urban area]].{{cite web|url=http://www.citypopulation.de/world/Agglomerations.html |title=Major Agglomerations of the World - Population Statistics and Maps |publisher=Citypopulation.de |date= |accessdate=September 26, 2017}} Moscow is recognized as a [[Federal cities of Russia|Russian federal city]]. Moscow is a major political, economic, cultural, and scientific centre of Russia and [[Eastern Europe]], as well as the [[Largest cities in Europe|largest city]] entirely on the [[Europe|European continent]]. {{Russian cities}} {{clear}} ==Rural life== [[Image:E7548-Cherlak-typical-street.jpg|thumb|[[Cherlak]], a typical small town - or a large village - in Western Siberia]] Rural life in Russia is distinct from many other nations. Relatively few Russian people live in [[village#Russia|villages]]—rural population accounted for 26% of the total population according to the [[Russian Census (2010)|2010 Russian Census]]. Some people own or rent village houses and use them as [[dachas]] (summer houses). ==See also== *[[Demographics of Siberia]] *[[Demography of Central Asia]] *[[Health in Russia]] *[[Indigenous small-numbered peoples of the North, Siberia and the Far East]] *[[Russian cross]] '''Census information:''' *[[Soviet Census]] *[[Russian Empire Census]] (1897) *[[Russian Census (2002)]] *[[Russian Census (2010)]] ==Notes== {{reflist|group=fn|refs= }} {{Notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * Gavrilova N.S., Gavrilov L.A. Population Research and Policy Review, 2000, 19: 397–419. ==External links== *Igor Beloborodov, [http://demographia.ru/articles_N/index.html?idR=71&idArt=1928 Demographic situation in Russia in 1992–2010] (report at the Moscow Demographic Summit — June 2011) *Nicholas Eberstadt, [http://www.nbr.org/publications/element.aspx?id=446 Russia's Peacetime Demographic Crisis: Dimensions, Causes, Implications] ([[National Bureau of Asian Research]] Project Report, May 2010) *Edited by Julie DaVanzo, Gwen Farnsworth [https://www.rand.org/pubs/conf_proceedings/CF124/index.html Russia's Demographic "Crisis"] 1996 [[RAND]] {{ISBN|0-8330-2446-9}} *Jessica Griffith [http://www.geog.le.ac.uk/russianheartland/WP03_Demographics_July04.pdf The Regional Consequences of Russia's Demographic Crisis] [[University of Leicester]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080227235653/http://eng.expert.ru/printissues/expert/2008/06/dalshe_sami/ Results of population policy and current demographic situation (2008)] *[https://www.census.gov/ipc/www/idb/informationGateway.php Interactive statistics for all countries], site of [[United States Census Bureau]]. *[http://www.prb.org/Publications/Datasheets/2009/2009wpds.aspx 2009 World Population Data Sheet] by the [[Population Reference Bureau]] *[http://www.sci.aha.ru/ATL/ra13a.htm Population density and distribution maps] (text is in Russian; the topmost map shows population density based on 1996 data) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051029152759/http://www.nupi.no/cgi-win/Russland/etnisk.exe?total Ethnic groups of Russia] *[http://longevity-science.org/Russia-Gavrilova-PAA-2005.pdf Problems with mortality data in Russia] *[http://www.demographia.ru/articles_N/index.html?idR=53&idArt=1363 V. Borisov "Demographic situation in Russia and the role of mortality in reproduction of population", 2005] (in English) *[[Russian Empire]]: **[http://www.eki.ee/books/redbook/index1.shtml The Red Book of the peoples of the Russian Empire] *{{ru icon}} [http://www.kommersant.ru/k-money-old/story.asp?m_id=32801 В погоне за малыми], an article about treatment of minorities in the [[Russian Empire]], [[Kommersant]]-Money, 25 October 2005 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070307104306/http://www.expert.ru/printissues/expert/2007/09/demograficheskaya_situaciya_v_rossii/ Choice between mass migration and birth rate increase as possible solutions of depopulation problem in Russia (in Russian)] * [https://archive.is/20150404121423/http://itbulk.org/population/population-by-country/ Build Russian population graph 1960 - 2013 (World Bank data)] * [https://archive.is/20150220095949/http://itbulk.org/population/population-projection-by-country/ Build Russian population projection graph till 2100 (United Nation data)] * [https://archive.is/20150404121433/http://itbulk.org/population/life-expectancy-by-country/ Build Russian life expectancy at birth graph 1950 - 2013 (United Nation data)] {{Ethnic groups in Russia}} {{Russia topics|state=collapsed}} {{Lists of Russians}} {{Demographics of Europe}} {{Europe topic|Ethnic groups in}} {{Asia in topic|Demographics of}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Demographics Of Russia}} [[Category:Demographics of Russia| ]] [[Category:Russian population groups]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Russia]] [[Category:Russian people]]

{{other people|Emmanuel Katongole}} {{Infobox person | name = Emmanuel Katongole | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1962|4|27|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Uganda]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = '''[[Namilyango College]]'''

'''[[Makerere University]]'''
{{small|([[Statistics|Bachelor of Statistics]])}}
{{small|([[Economics|MA Economic Policy & Planning]])}} | occupation = [[Business|Business Executive]] | years_active = 1990s — present | nationality = [[Uganda]]n | citizenship = [[Uganda]] | residence = [[Kampala]], [[Uganda]] | known_for = [[Investments]], [[Wealth]] | networth = | home_town = | title = '''[[Chief Executive Officer]]'''
[[Quality Chemical Industries Limited]] | spouse = }} '''Emmanuel Katongole''' is a [[Uganda]]n [[statistician]], [[economist]], [[businessman]], [[entrepreneur]], [[industrialist]] and [[philanthropist]]. He currently serves as the [[Chairman|Executive Chairman]] of [[Cipla Quality Chemical Industries Limited]] (CQCIL). CQCIL is the only company in [[Sub-Saharan Africa]], that is authorized to manufacture triple-combination anti retro-viral drugs.{{cite web |url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/The-founder-of-Quality-chemicals/-/688334/2036920/-/xafyigz/-/index.html | title=Emmanuel Katongole: The Founder of Quality Chemicals | access-date=28 March 2015 |date=18 October 2013 |location=Kampala |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] |author=Monitor Reporter}}{{cite web|access-date=28 March 2015 |date=12 November 2011 |url=http://www.thepromota.co.uk/interview-emmanuel-katongole-chief-executive-officer-quality-chemicals-industries-ltd/ | title=Interview: Emmanuel Katongole, Chief Executive Officer of Cipla Quality Chemicals Industries Limited |last=Mutenza | first=Willy |publisher=The Promota Magazine |location=London}} Since 2014, he concurrently serves as the chairman of the [[Uganda National Oil Company]].{{cite web|accessdate=26 January 2016| url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201504161183.html |date=16 April 2016| title=Uganda: Petroleum Directorate Formed As Oil Institutions Begin to Take Shape| first=Flavia | last=Nalubega | publisher=Oil In Uganda via [[AllAfrica.com]]| location=Kampala}} ==Education== He attended [[Namilyango College]] for his ''O Level'' and ''A Level'' education. He studied at [[Makerere University]], Uganda's largest and oldest [[public university]], graduating with the degree of [[Statistics|Bachelor of Statistics]] (B.Stat). His [[Economics|Master of Arts in Economic Policy and Planning]] (MA.EPP) was also obtained from Makerere University. He has attended numerous other short-term courses in Economics, Statistics and Management, from institutions in [[Uganda]] and [[Europe]]. ==Work History== In 1997, Emmanuel Katongole along with (a) Randall Tierney (b) Edward Martin (c) [[Francis Kitaka|Francis X. Kitaka]] (d) [[Frederick Kitaka|Frederick Mutebi Kitaka]] and (e) [[George Baguma]], founded a company called [[Quality Chemicals Limited]] (QCL). The company specialized in the importation of generic veterinary and human pharmaceuticals from [[India]]. Katongole served as [[Managing Director]] & [[Chief Executive Officer]] as well as shareholder from 1997 until 2007. In 2004, QCL convinced [[Cipla]], the [[India]]n drug maker, to form a joint venture and set up a pharmaceutical factory in Uganda. Ground was broken in 2005 and the factory was commissioned in 2007. The joint venture was originally known as [[Quality Chemical Industries Limited]].{{cite web |last=Byaruhanga | date=9 April 2012 |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-17639822|first=Catherine| title=Making Drugs Into Profit In Uganda |access-date=28 March 2015 |publisher=[[BBC News]]}} Katongole served as the Chief Executive Officer of QCIL from 2007 until 2013.{{cite web|access-date=2 August 2018 | url=https://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1216319/kitaka-brain-africa-eur-arvs-factory |title=Kitaka, The Brain Behind Africa'S First ARVs Factory |date=31 October 2007 | newspaper=[[New Vision]] |first=and Robert Kasozi |last=Elvis Basudde |location=Kampala}} In November 2013, [[Cipla]] took a controlling majority interest in QCIL, renaming the company [[CIPLAQCIL]] and appointing Katongole the [[Executive Chairman]] of the company. He remains a shareholder in the business.{{cite web|author=CQCIL | url=http://www.ciplaqcil.co.ug/about-us/board-of-directors/ | title=Board of Directors: Emmanuel Katongole: Executive Chairman |publisher=[[CIPLAQCIL]] (CQCIL) |access-date=28 March 2015 | date=30 November 2013 |location=Luzira, Kampala}} In July 2014, President Yoweri Museveni appointed Katongole to serve as Chairman of the Uganda National Oil Company.{{cite web| url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/News/National/Rotary-work-got-me-oil-job--says-Katongole/-/688334/2382514/-/rjslu4z/-/index.html |title=Rotary work got me oil job, says Katongole |access-date=26 January 2016 |date=13 July 2014 |first=Abdulaziizi K. | last=Tumusiime |newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] |location=Kampala}} ==Business Interests== Emmanuel Katongole owns the following businesses either wholly or in part: * Vero Food Industries Limited - Located at Kampala's Industrial and Business Park, [[Namanve]], [[Wakiso District]] * Tinosoft Limited - An Information Technology company, located in [[Kampala]] * Quality Chemical Industries Limited - A manufacturer of antimalarial and antiretroviral medications; located in [[Luzira]], [[Kampala]] ==Other responsibilities== He is a member of the [[Initiative for Global Development]] (IGD) - Frontier 100, a group that joins the most successful business leaders operating in frontier markets, with business leaders from [[Europe]] and the [[United States]]. The Governing Council of IGD is co-chaired by [[Madeleine Albright]] and [[Colin Powell|General Colin L. Powell]], both former secretaries of State of the [[United States of America]]. Emmanuel Katongole is [[Rotary Club|Rotarian]] and is a member of the [[Muyenga|Rotary Club of Muyenga]]. He has also served as the District Governor for Rotary District 9211, which comprises [[Tanzania]] and [[Uganda]]. In August 2014, Emmanuel Katongole was named Chairman of the [[Uganda National Oil Company]]{{cite web|accessdate=29 March 2014|first=Ronald| url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201408281499.html|date=28 August 2014|title=Uganda: Oil Reserves Now Estimated At 6.5 Billion Barrels| last=Musoke|newspaper=[[The Independent (Uganda)]] via [[AllAfrica.com]]}} ==Photos== * [http://www.monitor.co.ug/image/view/-/2036922/highRes/603302/-/maxw/600/-/m4twqs/-/national001px.jpg Photo At Monitor.co.ug] ==See also== *[[Quality Chemicals Limited]] *[[Uganda Securities Exchange]] *[[Frederick Kitaka]] *[[Francis Kitaka]] *[[George Baguma]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.ciplaqcil.co.ug/ Website of Cipla Quality Chemicals Limited] *[http://www.qcil.co.ug/ Website of Quality Chemicals Limited] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Katongole, Emmanuel}} [[Category:Ugandan businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Ganda people]] [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Ugandan statisticians]] [[Category:Ugandan economists]] [[Category:Makerere University alumni]] [[Category:People educated at Namilyango College]] [[Category:Ugandan Roman Catholics]]

{{Use British English|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox fashion designer |image=Georgina Chapman at Met Opera (cropped).jpg | |caption=Chapman in September 2008 |name=Georgina Chapman |nationality=British |birth_name=Georgina Rose Chapman{{cite web|url=https://www.duedil.com/director/909777970/georgina-rose-chapman|title=DueDil|publisher=Duedil.com|accessdate=5 October 2017}} |birth_date={{Birth date and age|df=yes|1976|4|14}} |birth_place=[[London]], [[England]] |death_date= |death_place= |occupation=[[Wardrobe stylist|Designer]], [[Actor|actress]] |yearsactive=2001–present |alma mater= [[Marlborough College]]
[[Wimbledon College of Arts|Wimbledon School of Art]]
[[Chelsea College of Art and Design]] |label_name= Marchesa |significant_design= |awards= |spouse= {{Marriage|[[Harvey Weinstein]]|2007|October 10, 2017|end=separated}} |children = 2 |}} '''Georgina Rose Chapman''' (born 14 April 1976) is an English fashion designer and actress. Together with [[Keren Craig]], she is a co-founder of the fashion label [[Marchesa (brand)|Marchesa]]. ==Life and career== Chapman was born in London, England, the daughter of Caroline Wonfor, a journalist, and [[Brian Chapman (businessman)|Brian Chapman]], a co-owner of the coffee company Percol.{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.it/en/encyclo/designers/c/georgina-chapman|title=Georgina Chapman – Vogue.it|website=Vogue|accessdate=5 October 2017}}{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/08/fashion/08MOTHERS.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | first=Chloe | last=Malle | title=Fashion Designers Recall Their Mothers' Style | date=6 May 2011}} Chapman grew up in [[Richmond, London|Richmond]], southwest London. Chapman attended [[Marlborough College]] in Wiltshire. In her 20s, Chapman modelled in an advertisement for [[Head & Shoulders]], a dandruff shampoo, and one for throat lozenges Soothers.{{Cite news|url=http://www.fashionelite.com/profile/georgina-chapman/|title=Georgina Chapman|date=2016-09-21|work=Fashion Elite|access-date=2017-11-24|language=en-US}} Chapman met future business partner Keren Craig while they were students at [[Chelsea College of Art and Design]].{{cite web|url=http://www.marchesa.com/|title=Marchesa|publisher=Marchesa.com|accessdate=5 October 2017}} Chapman graduated from [[Wimbledon School of Art]] in 2001 and began her career as a [[costume designer]].{{cite news|last1=Khomami|first1=Nadia|title=Georgina Chapman: no longer behind Harvey Weinstein, still behind a global brand|url=https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2017/oct/11/georgina-chapman-no-longer-behind-harvey-weinstein-still-behind-a-global-brand|accessdate=6 February 2018|publisher=The Guardian|date=October 11, 2017}} After graduation, Chapman appeared in various television shows and films. In 2004, she and Craig launched [[Marchesa (brand)|Marchesa]], named after socialite Marchesa [[Luisa Casati]]. Investors include Giuseppe Cipriani and [[Steve Witkoff]].Fashion Mini: February 2008{{Clarify|date=April 2012}} In 2006, the label was named one of the [[Council of Fashion Designers of America|CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund's]] top 10 finalists.{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/fashion/fashionshows/designers/bios/marchesa/|title=Marchesa Designer Profile|website=New York|accessdate=5 October 2017}} According to the 2015 [[Sunday Times Rich List|''Sunday Times'' Rich List]], Chapman has a net worth of £15 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.richestlifestyle.com/networth/georgina-chapman-net-worth/|title= Georgina Chapman Net Worth According to the Sunday Times|publisher=Richestlifestyle.com|accessdate=15 July 2015}} Since 2012, Chapman has been a judge on ''[[Project Runway: All Stars]]''.{{cite press release|last=Seidman|first=Robert|title='Project Runway All Stars' to Premiere Thursday, January 5 on Lifetime|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/11/29/project-runway-all-stars-to-premiere-thursday-january-5-on-lifetime/112103/|work=TV by the Numbers|accessdate=12 October 2017|date=29 November 2011}} ==Personal life== Chapman was born with [[Pigeon toe|femoral anteversion]], which caused her toes to point inward while walking. At the age of 8, she was diagnosed with [[dyslexia]]. She is good friends with actor [[David Oyelowo]], whom she has known since she was 18. Chapman started dating film producer [[Harvey Weinstein]] in December 2004 after he left his first wife. They married on 15 December 2007 in [[Connecticut]], [[United States|U.S.]] The couple divided their time between a [[West Village]] townhouse, a seafront home in [[Westport, Connecticut]], and a mansion in [[Los Angeles]]. Chapman gave birth to the couple's first child, daughter India Pearl, on 30 August 2010.{{cite web|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2010/09/01/harvey-weinstein-georgina-chapman-welcome-daughter-india-pearl/|title=Harvey Weinstein, Georgina Chapman Welcome Daughter India Pearl|website=People|accessdate=5 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/pagesix/another_girl_UNp4svPiXNC1dwTxeSbWAK|title=Weinstein, Chapman blessed with another girl|date=31 August 2010|website=New York Post|accessdate=5 October 2017}} On 11 April 2013, they had a son, Dashiell Max Robert.{{cite web |url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2013/04/23/harvey-weinstein-happy-to-have-son/#more-185195 |title=Harvey Weinstein: Why I’m Happy to Finally Have a Son |website=People |date=23 April 2013}} On 10 October 2017, Chapman announced she was divorcing Weinstein after more than 90 women [[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse allegations|made accusations]] of rape, assault, or sexual harassment against him.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/harvey-weinstein-wife-georgina-chapman-divorcing-divorce-1202586378/|title=Harvey Weinstein's Wife Georgina Chapman Divorcing Him|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|first=Pat|last=Saperstein|date=10 October 2017|accessdate=10 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://people.com/movies/harvey-weinstein-wife-georgina-chapman-separating/|title=Harvey Weinstein's Wife Georgina Chapman Is Leaving Him: 'My Heart Breaks for All the Women Who Have Suffered'|website=[[People (magazine)|People]]|first1=Mary|last1=Green|first2=Jodi|last2=Gugleimi|date=10 October 2017|accessdate=10 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/harvey-weinsteins-wife-georgina-chapman-says-she-is-leaving-him-1047559|title=Harvey Weinstein's Wife Georgina Chapman Says She Is Leaving Him|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|first=Stephanie|last=Chan|date=10 October 2017|accessdate=10 October 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Van Meter|first1=Jonathan|title=Georgina Chapman on Life After Harvey Weinstein|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/georgina-chapman-life-after-harvey-weinstein|work=Vogue|date=May 10, 2018}} ==Filmography== * ''[[Project Runway: All Stars]]'' (2012–present) as herself, judge * ''[[Gossip Girl (TV series)|Gossip Girl]]'' (2009) as herself * ''[[Awake (film)|Awake]]'' (2007) as Penny Carver Elliot * ''[[The Nanny Diaries (film)|The Nanny Diaries]]'' (2007) as TriBeCa fashionista * ''Don't'' – Fake Trailer in between ''[[Planet Terror]]'' and ''[[Death Proof]]'' in ''[[Grindhouse (film)|Grindhouse]]'' (2007) * ''[[Factory Girl (film)|Factory Girl]]'' (2006) as interviewer * ''Project Catwalk'' (2006) TV Series as herself, guest panellist on season 1, episode 9 * ''[[Derailed (2005 film)|Derailed]]'' (2005) as Candy * ''[[The Business (film)|The Business]]'' (2005) as Carly * ''[[Match Point]]'' (2005) as Nola co-worker * ''Danny the Dog'' (2005) as floozy 1 * ''Zemanovaload'' (2005) as Jenna * ''Rosemary & Thyme'' as Celia Llewellyn (1 episode, 2004) * ''[[Bride & Prejudice]]'' (2004) as Anne * ''A Soldier's Tunic'' (2004) as Katherine Cranborn * ''Piccadilly Jim'' (2004) as Connie 1 *''[[Shanghai Knights]]'' (2003) as debutante * ''Sons & Lovers'' (2003) (TV) as Louie * ''Jeffrey Archer: The Truth'' (2002) (TV) as secretary * ''Desire'' (2001) as Eve ==References== {{Reflist| refs= {{cite news | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/kate-middleton/10719247/Why-everyone-wants-a-Marlborough-missus.html | title = Why everyone wants a Marlborough missus | newspaper = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | author = Victoria Lambert | date = 29 March 2014 | location = London | accessdate = 9 February 2015 | deadurl = No | quote = And it hasn't just produced "better halves" for politicians – its reach of influence stretches across the internet, fashion, the BBC and Hollywood, through old girls Amanda Rosenberg (dating Google founder Sergey Brin); Amanda Harlech (former wife of Lord Harlech, and muse to Karl Lagerfeld); Elizabeth Ann Clough (long-term partner of Jeremy Paxman); and Georgina Chapman, "wife of" Oscar-winning producer Harvey Weinstein. }} }} ==External links== {{about|the mathematician|the politician|Gerhard Frey (politician)}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Gerhard Frey | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Gerhard Frey (matematico).jpg | image_size = 220px | alt = | caption = Gerhard Frey at [[Mathematical Research Institute of Oberwolfach|Oberwolfach]] in 2004 | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1944}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | nationality = [[Germany|German]] | fields = [[Mathematics]] | workplaces = [[Saarland University]]
[[University of Duisburg-Essen]] | alma_mater = [[University of Heidelberg]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = [[Peter Roquette]] | doctoral_students = [[Tanja Lange]] | known_for = | awards = }} '''Gerhard Frey''' ({{IPA-de|fʁaɪ|lang}}; born 1944) is a [[Germany|German]] [[mathematician]], known for his work in [[number theory]]. His [[Frey curve]], a construction of an [[elliptic curve]] from a purported solution to the [[Fermat's last theorem|Fermat equation]], was central to [[Wiles's proof of Fermat's Last Theorem]].{{cite web| url= http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/are-mathematicians-finall/ | title= Are mathematicians finally satisfied with Andrew Wiles's proof of Fermat's Last Theorem? Why has this theorem been so difficult to prove? | author=Helen G. Grundman | date= 21 October 1999 | publisher= Scientific American | access-date=21 August 2016}}{{cite web| url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/1999/jul/21/technology | title=Beyond Fermat's last theorem | author=Keith Devlin | date=21 July 1999 | publisher=[[The Guardian]] | access-date=21 August 2016}} ==Education and career== He studied [[mathematics]] and [[physics]] at the [[University of Tübingen]], graduating in 1967. He continued his [[postgraduate]] studies at [[Heidelberg University]], where he received his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in 1970,{{MathGenealogy|29309}} and his [[Habilitation]] in 1973. He was assistant professor at Heidelberg University from 1969–1973, professor at the [[University of Erlangen-Nuremberg|University of Erlangen]] (1973–1975) and at [[Saarland University]] (1975–1990). Until 2009, he held a chair for [[number theory]] at the [[Institute for Experimental Mathematics]] at the [[University of Duisburg-Essen]], campus [[Essen]]. Frey was a visiting scientist at several universities and research institutions, including the [[Ohio State University]], [[Harvard University]], the [[University of California, Berkeley]], the [[Mathematical Sciences Research Institute]] (MSRI), the Institute for Advanced Studies at [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]], and the [[Instituto Nacional de Matemática Pura e Aplicada]] (IMPA) in [[Rio de Janeiro]]. Frey was also the co-editor of the journal ''[[Manuscripta Mathematica]]''. ==Research contributions== His research areas are [[number theory]] and [[Arithmetic|arithmetical]] [[geometry]], as well as applications to [[coding theory]] and [[cryptography]]. In 1985, Frey pointed out a connection between [[Fermat's last theorem]] and the [[Taniyama-Shimura Conjecture]], and this connection was made precise shortly thereafter by [[Kenneth Ribet]], who proved that the Taniyama-Shimura Conjecture implies Fermat's last theorem.{{cite book |first=Piergiorgio |last=Odifreddi |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zAIar8Ee80QC&pg=PA86 |title=The Mathematical Century: The 30 Greatest Problems of the Last 100 years |publisher=[[Princeton University Press]] |year=2006 |isbn=0-691-12805-7 |page=87 }} This approach provided a framework for the subsequent successful attack on Fermat's last theorem by [[Andrew Wiles]] in the 1990s.{{cite news |first=Richard |last=Bernstein |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/28/books/books-times-following-proof-fermat-s-theorem-far-horizon-pure-reason.html?pagewanted=1 |title=Following a Proof of Fermat's Theorem to the Far Horizon of Pure Reason |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=November 28, 1997 |accessdate=January 24, 2010 }} In 1998, Frey proposed the idea of [[Weil descent]] attack for elliptic curves over finite fields with composite degree. As a result of this attack, [[Cryptography|cryptographers]] lost their interest in these curves.{{citation|title=Guide to Elliptic Curve Cryptography|first1=Darrel|last1=Hankerson|first2=Scott|last2=Vanstone|first3=Alfred J.|last3=Menezes|publisher=Springer|year=2004|isbn=9780387952734|pages=170–171}}.. ==Awards and honors== Frey was awarded the Gauss medal of the ''Braunschweigische Wissenschaftliche Gesellschaft'' in 1996 for his work on [[Fermat's Last Theorem]].[http://www.bwg-niedersachsen.de/cgi-bin/moin.cgi/_dcber_20die_20BWG/Die_20Gauss_20Medaille?action=highlight&value=Frey Die Gauß Medaille]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (in German), Braunschweigische Wissenschaftliche Gesellschaft. Accessed January 24, 2010 Since 1998, he has been a member of the [[Göttingen Academy of Sciences]].{{cite web |url=http://www.uni-goettingen.de/de/document/download/3716a19481c54eb4f7ff7c65c6429712.pdf/kompetenzhandbuch_web2.pdf |title=Member list |language=German |work=[[Göttingen Academy of Sciences]] |accessdate=January 24, 2010 }} In 2006, he received the ''Certicom ECC Visionary Award'' for his contributions to [[elliptic curve cryptography]].{{cite paper |url=http://www.securitytechnet.com/resource/crypto/code&cipher/CC-06-final.pdf |title=Certicom ECC Visionary Award |work=Code and Cipher |volume=3 |year=2006 |issue=1 |page=1 |accessdate=January 24, 2010 }} ==See also== *[[Fermat's last theorem]] *[[Elliptic curve]]s ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.esaga.uni-due.de/gerhard.frey/ Gerhard Frey's webpage at University Duisburg-Essen] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Frey, Gerhard}} [[Category:20th-century German mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century mathematicians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:University of Tübingen alumni]] [[Category:Heidelberg University alumni]] [[Category:Heidelberg University faculty]] [[Category:Ohio State University faculty]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley faculty]] [[Category:Harvard University staff]] [[Category:Modern cryptographers]] [[Category:Number theorists]] [[Category:People from Erlangen]] [[Category:University of Erlangen-Nuremberg faculty]] [[Category:University of Duisburg-Essen faculty]] [[Category:Saarland University faculty]] [[Category:Hebrew University of Jerusalem faculty]]

{{good article}} {{use Australian English|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox sportsperson | headercolor = green | textcolor = yellow | name = Hannah Dodd | image = 150611 - Hannah Dodd - 3b - 2012 Team processing.jpg | image_size = | caption = 2012 Australian Paralympic Team
portrait of Dodd | birth_name = | fullname = | nickname = | nationality = {{AUS}} | residence = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1992|4|27}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | height = | weight = | website = | country = Australia | sport = [[Equestrian at the Summer Paralympics|Equestrian]]
[[Wheelchair basketball]] | event = | collegeteam = | club = Sydney University Flames | team = | disability_class = [[Grade 4 (classification)|Grade IV]]
[[1 point player|1.0]] | turnedpro = | coach = | retired = | coaching = | worlds = | regionals = | nationals = | olympics = | paralympics = | highestranking = | pb = | medaltemplates= {{MedalSport |Wheelchair basketball}} {{MedalCompetition|U25 Women's World Championships}} {{MedalSilver|2015 Beijing, China|Women's wheelchair basketball}}}} '''Hannah Dodd''' (born 27 April 1992) is an Australian [[Grade 4 (classification)|Grade IV]] [[Equestrian at the Summer Paralympics|equestrian]] and [[1 point player|1.0 point]] [[wheelchair basketball]] player who represented [[Australia at the 2012 Summer Paralympics|Australia]] in [[equestrian at the 2012 Summer Paralympics]] in London, coming 11th and 12th in her events. Switching to wheelchair basketball, she made her debut with the [[Australia women's national wheelchair basketball team|national team]] at the Osaka Cup in February 2015. In 2008, Dodd was the Australian national Grade IV para-equestrian champion. She was runner-up in 2009, and won the Australian national championships again in 2011, along with the Oceania Championships and the National Titles team events. By 2012, she was the top-ranked Australian competitor in her event and class. After the London Paralympics, Dodd took up [[wheelchair basketball]]. She started playing for the Sydney University Flames in the [[Women's National Wheelchair Basketball League]] in 2013, made her debut with the [[Australia women's national wheelchair basketball team|national team]] at the Osaka Friendship Games in [[Osaka]] in February 2015, winning bronze, and was part of the Under 25 team at the [[2015 Women's U25 Wheelchair Basketball World Championship]] in [[Beijing]] in July 2015, winning silver. ==Personal== Hannah Dodd was born on 27 April 1992,{{cite web |url=http://www.equestrian.org.au/?ID=29398 |title=Hannah Dodd |publisher=Equestrian Australia |accessdate=20 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819085315/http://www.equestrian.org.au/?ID=29398 |archivedate=19 August 2012}} and is from [[Arcadia, New South Wales]]. She has [[sacral agenesis]] and [[spina bifida]] with upper limb [[dystonia]],{{cite web|first=Lawrence |last=Machado |url=http://rouse-hill-times.whereilive.com.au/news/story/hannahs-bravery-shines-through-the-pain-for-australia/ |title=Hannah's bravery shines through the pain for Australia |publisher=Rouse Hill Times |date= |accessdate=25 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121231/http://rouse-hill-times.whereilive.com.au/news/story/hannahs-bravery-shines-through-the-pain-for-australia/ |archivedate=31 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and is missing four vertebrae in her back. When she was about a year old, her kidneys started failing. Her entire renal system needed to be reconstructed. She has two older brothers. She can walk with the aide of a [[Brace (orthopaedic)|caliper]], and also uses a wheelchair. {{As of|2012}}, she is a horse riding teacher and student at the [[University of Western Sydney]] where she is majoring in sports and exercise science. ==Equestrian== Dodd is a [[Grade 4 (classification)|Grade IV]] equestrian competitor, coached by Peter Turner. Due to her sacral agenesis, when she rides her horse, she dislocates several bones every time, but as a result of anti-doping rules, she has had to find alternative ways of coping with pain associated with riding. [[File:010912 - Hannah Dodd - 3b - 2012 Summer Paralympics (01).JPG|thumb|left|Dodd riding at the 2012 London Paralympics]] Dodd has been around horses since she was four months old, and was able to ride on her own by the time she was two years old, before she learned to walk. The sport gave her a degree of independence. She started competing in 2005, and first represented Australia in 2006, winning her first test in England that year.{{cite web |url=http://london2012.paralympic.org.au/hannah-dodd |title=Hannah Dodd – London 2012 – Official Australian Paralympic Team Website |publisher=Australian Paralympic Committee |accessdate=3 September 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160811131700/http://london2012.paralympic.org.au/hannah-dodd |archivedate=11 August 2016 |df=dmy-all }}In 2008, she became the youngest-ever winner of the Australian national championships. She finished first at the March 2009 inter-schools cup at the [[St Ives, New South Wales|St Ives]] Showground, and second at the 2009 Australian national championships, but her horse, Lucifer's Dream, was injured in 2009. In 2009 and 2010, she searched for another horse to assist her in getting through Paralympic qualification.{{cite web|last=Priestley |first=Andrew |url=http://north-shore-times.whereilive.com.au/news/story/hannah-needs-another-horse-in-a-hurry/ |title=Hannah needs another horse in a hurry |publisher=North Shore Times |date= |accessdate=25 July 2012}}{{cite news|last=Murray |first=Therese |url=http://hills-shire-times.whereilive.com.au/news/story/galstons-hannah-dodd-needs-a-ride-to-london-paralympics/ |title=Galston's Hannah Dodd needs a ride to London Paralympics |newspaper=Hills Shire Times |date= |accessdate=25 July 2012}} She won the Australian national championships again in 2011, along with the Oceania Championships and the National Titles team events. By 2012, she was the top-ranked Australian competitor in her event and class.{{cite news|title=Para TROOPER|newspaper=The Weekly Times|location=Melbourne, Australia|date=6 June 2012|first=Emily|last=Portelli|page=H14}} Dodd was selected to represent [[Australia at the 2012 Summer Paralympics|Australia]] at the [[2012 Summer Paralympics]] in London in [[equestrian at the 2012 Summer Paralympics|equestrian events]] with her horse Waikiwi.{{cite web|url=http://www.paralympic.org.au/team/hannah-dodd |title=Hannah Dodd |publisher=[[Australian Paralympic Committee]] |year=2012 |accessdate=13 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712095313/https://www.paralympic.org.au/team/hannah-dodd |archivedate=12 July 2012 |df= }} This page erroneously gives her date of birth as 27 February 1992.{{cite news|first=Iain |last=Hyndman |url=http://www.wanganuichronicle.co.nz/news/worldwide-lands-london-spot/1455867/ |title=Worldwide lands London spot |newspaper=Wanganui Chronicle |date=17 July 2012 |accessdate=25 July 2012}} These Games were her first, and she was the youngest Australian equestrian competitor. A fund raiser was organised by [[Arcadia, New South Wales]], residents.{{cite web |url=http://hornsby-advocate.whereilive.com.au/news/story/community-push-to-help-local-paralympian/ |title=Community push to help local Paralympian |publisher=Hornsby & Upper North Shore Advocate |date= |accessdate=25 July 2012}} While her own costs and the cost of her horse were covered by [[Australian Paralympic Committee]] and [[Equestrian Australia]], funds were required for her coach. She was placed 12th in the Individual Championship Test – Grade IV, and 11th in the Individual Freestyle Test – Grade IV and Team Test – Grade IV.{{cite web |url=http://london2012.paralympic.org.au/sports/equestrian-dressage?qt-sports=4#qt-sports |title=Equestrian – Dressage |publisher=London 2012 – Official Australian Paralympic Team Website |accessdate=20 July 2014}} ==Wheelchair basketball== After the London Paralympics, Dodd took up [[wheelchair basketball]]. She started for the Sydney University Flames in the [[Women's National Wheelchair Basketball League]] in 2013. She has to strap her fingers and wrists, and usually dislocates a shoulder during a game. "I've had a few bangs and scrapes and been tipped out of my chair a few times," she concedes, "but it's really fun. The fast pace really gives you an adrenalin kick and the girls I play with are awesome."{{cite news |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]| location = [[Sydney]]||url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/newslocal/the-hills/arcadia8217s-hannah-dodd-swaps-paralympic-dressage-for-basketball/story-fngr8j1q-1226651644194 |title=Arcadia's Hannah Dodd swaps Paralympic dressage for basketball |first=Lawrence |last=Machado |date=27 May 2013 }} "If I have chose between my two sports for Rio," she said, "I will go with basketball." Dodd made her debut with the [[Australia women's national wheelchair basketball team|national team]], known as the Gliders, at the Osaka Cup in [[Osaka]] in February 2015.{{cite web |url=http://www.basketball.net.au/gliders-defeat-canada-in-osaka-friendship-games/ |title=Gliders Defeat Canada to Open Osaka Friendship Games |publisher=[[Basketball Australia]] |accessdate=2 May 2015 }} The Gliders won bronze.{{cite web |url=http://britishwheelchairbasketball.co.uk/gbwba/index.cfm/news/osaka-cup-2015-great-britain-take-silver-medal/ |title=Osaka Cup 2015: Great Britain take Silver Medal |publisher=British Wheelchair Basketball |accessdate=3 September 2015 }} In June 2015, Dodd was selected as part of the under 25 team (known as the Devils) for the [[ 2015 Women's U25 Wheelchair Basketball World Championship]] in [[Beijing]] in July. The Devils won silver.{{cite web|url=http://www.paralympic.org.au/news/devils-earn-silver-iwbf-u25-world-championships |title=Devils earn silver at the IWBF U25 World Championships |publisher=[[Australian Paralympic Committee]] |accessdate=9 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150710022046/http://www.paralympic.org.au/news/devils-earn-silver-iwbf-u25-world-championships |archivedate=10 July 2015 |df= }} By this time her health had deteriorated. She had to use a wheelchair much of the time, and her classification had dropped to a [[2.5 point player]].{{cite news |title=Paralympian Dodd a Dare Devil |first=Lawrence |last=Machado |newspaper=Rouse Hill Times |date=25 June 2015 |url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/newslocal/news/paralympian-dodd-a-dare-devil/story-fngr8gwi-1227413286808 |accessdate=29 June 2015}} In 2015, she was reclassified a 2.0,{{cite web |url=http://www.foxsportspulse.com/team_info.cgi?action=PSTATS&pID=200519425&client=1-4219-72986-369135-24482784 |title=Player statistics for Hannah Dodd (2.0) |publisher=Fox Sports |accessdate=3 September 2015 }} and in June 2017, as a [[1.0 point player|1.0]].{{cite web |url=http://websites.sportstg.com/team_info.cgi?action=PSTATS&pID=202015076&client=1-6734-84472-416092-25341823 |title=Player statistics for Hannah Dodd (1.0) |publisher=Basketball Australia |via=SportsTG |access-date=29 July 2017 }} {{clear}} ==External links== * {{YouTube|id=UVBZFmxNL0 |title=Hannah Dodd – Para-Equestrian}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{2012 Australian Paralympic Team}} {{Portal bar|Australia|Basketball|Biography|Paralympics|Women's sport}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dodd, Hannah}} [[Category:1992 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Paralympic equestrians of Australia]] [[Category:Equestrians at the 2012 Summer Paralympics]] [[Category:Australian women's wheelchair basketball players]] [[Category:People with spina bifida]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Sydney]] [[Category:Sportswomen from New South Wales]]

revision.text:
{{about|names of Hebrew-language origin|Jewish names|Jewish name|Hebrew surnames|Hebraization of surnames}} {{refimprove|date=July 2013}} {{use mdy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Judaism}} '''Hebrew names''' are [[name]]s that have a [[Hebrew language]] origin, classically from the [[Hebrew Bible]].{{cite book|author1=Mordecai Schreiber|author2=Alvin I. Schiff|author3=Leon Klenicki|title=The Shengold Jewish Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DK5K72JymAEC&pg=PA190|year=2003|publisher=Schreiber Pub.|isbn=978-1-887563-77-2|page=190}}. Archived [https://web.archive.org/web/20170217052951/https://books.google.com/books?id=DK5K72JymAEC&pg=PA190&dq=%22Hebrew+name%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ButHUYbFA7jI4AP164CgBw&ved=0CEwQ6AEwAw here] They are mostly used by Jews and Christians, but many are also adapted to the [[Islam]]ic world, particularly if a Hebrew name is mentioned in the [[Qur'an]] (example: ''Ibrahim'' is a common Arabic name from the Hebrew ''Avraham''). A typical Hebrew name can have many different forms, having been adapted to the [[phonology|phonologies]] of many different [[language]]s. A common Jewish practice worldwide is to give a Hebrew name to a child that is used religiously throughout his or her lifetime. Not all Hebrew names are strictly Hebrew in origin; some names may have been borrowed from other ancient languages, including from [[Egyptian language|Egyptian]], [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]], [[Phoenician language|Phoenician]], or [[Canaanite language|Canaanite]]. ==Names of Hebrew origin== Hebrew names used by [[Jew]]s (along with many Hebrew names used in [[Christendom]]) often come from the [[Tanakh]], also known as the [[Hebrew Bible]] or [[Old Testament]]. Many of these names are thought to have been adapted from Hebrew phrases and expressions, bestowing special meaning or the unique circumstances of birth to the one who receives that name. [[Theophoric name]]s are those which include a form of a divine name, such by adding the suffix אל ''-el'', meaning "God," forming names such as מיכאל ''[[Michael]]'' ("who is like God?") and גבריאל ''[[Gabriel]]'' ("man of God"). Another common form of theophory is the use of the [[Tetragrammaton]] as the basis for a suffix; the most common abbreviations used by Jews are יה ''-yāh''/''-iyyāh'' and יהו ''-yāhû''/''-iyyāhû''/''-ayhû'', forming names such as ישׁעיהו ''[[Isaiah|Yəšaʻªyāhû]]'' (Isaiah), צדקיהו ''[[Zedekiah|Ṣiḏqiyyāhû]]'' (Zedekiah) and שׂריה ''[[Seraiah|Śərāyāh]]'' (Seraiah). Most Christian usage is of the shorter suffix preferred in [[translation]]s of the [[Septuagint|Bible]] to European languages: Greek -ιας ''-ias'' and English [[Jah|-iah]], producing names such as Τωβιας ''[[Tobias|Tōbias]]'' (Tobias, Toby) instead of ''Tobiyyahu'' and Ιερεμίας ''[[Jeremiah|Ieremias]]'' (Jeremiah, Jeremy) instead of ''Yirmeyahu''. In addition to devotion to Elohim and YHWH, names could also be sentences of praise in their own right. The name טוביהו ''[[Tobiah|Ṭôḇiyyāhû]]'' means "Good of/is the LORD." == Names of Aramaic origin == Judæo-Aramaic was the vernacular language at the time of [[Jesus]], and was also the language used to write parts of the [[Book of Daniel]], the [[Book of Ezra]], and the entire Jewish Babylonian [[Talmud]]. Aramaic remained the [[lingua franca]] of the Middle East until the time of Islam. Judæo-Aramaic names include עבד־נגו ''[[Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego#Fiery furnace|ʻĂḇēḏ-nəḡô]]'', בר־תלמי ''[[Bartholomew|Bar-Talmay]]'' and תום ''[[Thomas (name)|Tôm]]'', as well as [[Bar Kochba]]. ==Hebrew-Greek names== Due to the [[Hellenization|Hellenisation]] of the Eastern Mediterranean and the movement of Jews around the area, many Hebrew names were adapted to Greek, reinforced by the translation of the Tanakh in the [[Septuagint]] with many Hellenized names. Many of the names in the [[New Testament]] are of Hebrew and Aramaic origin, but were adapted to the Greek by Hellenistic Christian writers such as [[Paul of Tarsus]]. Such Hebræo-Greek names include Ἰησοῦς ''[[Jesus|Iēsous]]'' (originally from ישׁוע ''Yēšûªʻ''), Νῶε ''[[Noah|Nōē]]'' (originally from נח ''Nōªḥ''), Ἰσαΐας ''[[Isaiah|Isaias]]'' (originally from ישׁעיהו ''Yəšaʻªyāhû''), Ἰσραήλ ''[[Israel|Israēl]]'' (originally from ישראל ''Yiśrā’ēl''). Also, some Jews of the time had Greek [[Gentile]] names themselves, such as the Christian [[Luke (name)|Luke]] (Greek Λουκᾶς ''Loukas''). Though used by some Jews at the time, these names are generally not associated with Jews today, and are considered characteristically Greek and largely confined to use by Christians. Hebrew forms of the names exist, but they are extremely rare. ==Hebræo-Latin names== Many Hebrew names were adapted into Latin, some via Greek. Such names include Jesus (from Greek Ιησους ''Iēsous'') and [[Maria (given name)|Maria]] (from Greek Μαριαμ ''Mariam'', originally from Hebrew מרים ''[[Miriam|Miryām]]''). Also, some Jews during [[Roman Empire|Roman]] times also had Latin names for themselves, such as the Christian evangelist [[Mark the Evangelist|Mark]] (Latin [[Marcus (name)|Marcus]]). As was the case with contemporary Jewish names of Greek origin, most of these Latin names are generally not associated with Jews today, and today retain a Roman and Christian character. == Hebræo-Arabic names == With the rise of Islam and the establishment of an Arab [[Caliphate]], the [[Arabic language]] became the lingua franca of the Middle East and some parts of [[Berber people|Berber]] [[North Africa]]. Islamic scripture such as the Qurʼan, however, contains many names of Hebrew origin (often via Aramaic), and there were Jewish and Christian [[minority group|minorities]] living under Arab Islamic rule. As such, many Hebrew names had been adapted to Arabic, and could be found in the Arab world. Jews and Christians generally used the Arabic adaptions of these names, just as in the present English-speaking Jews (and sometimes Muslims) often use Anglicized versions (Joshua rather than Yəhôšúªʼ, for instance.) While most such names are common to traditional Arabic translations of the Bible, a few differ; for instance, Arabic-speaking Christians use ''Yasūʻ'' instead of ''[[Jesus in Islam|ʻĪsā]]'' for "[[Jesus]]". Such Hebræo-Arabic names include: *[[Job in Islam|ʼAyyūb]] أيّوب (from Hebrew איוב ''[[Book of Job|ʼIyyôḇ]]'') (Job) *[[Joseph in Islam|Yūsuf]] يوسف (from Hebrew יוסף ''[[Joseph (given name)|Yôsēp̄]]'') (Joseph) *[[David in Islam|Dāʼūd]] داۇد (from Hebrew דוד ''[[David|Dāwiḏ]]'') (David) *[[Ishmael in Islam|ʼIsmāʻīl]] اسماعيل (from Hebrew ישׁמעאל ''[[Ishmael|Yišmāʻêl]]'') (Ishmael) *[[Isaac in Islam|ʼIsḥāq]] إسحاق (from Hebrew יצחק ''[[Isaac|Yiṣḥāq]]'') (Isaac) *[[Jacob in Islam|Yaʻqūb]] يعقوب (from Hebrew יעקב ''[[Jacob|Yaʻªqōḇ]]'') (Jacob) *[[Adam in Islam|ʼĀdam]] آدم (from Hebrew אדם ''[[Adam (name)|ʼĀḏām]]'') (Adam) *[[Hawwa|Ḥawwāʼ]] حواء (from Hebrew חוה ''[[Adam and Eve|Ḥawwāh]]'') (Eve) The influence of Aramaic is observable in several names, notably ʼIsḥāq (Isaac), where the [[Syriac language|Syriac]] form is simply ''Îsḥāq'', contrasting with more Hebraic forms such as Yaʻqūb (Jacob). Some of these Arabic names preserve original Hebrew pronunciations that were later changed by regular sound shifts; ''migdal'', recorded in the New Testament as ''Magdal''ene and in Palestinian Arabic as ''Majdala'', which turned ''a'' in unstressed closed syllables into ''i''. Typically, Hebrew אל ''-ʼēl'' was adapted as ـايل ''-īl'', and Hebrew יה ''-yāh'' as ـيا ''-yāʼ''. == Hebræo-English names == [[James I of England]] commissioned a [[translation]] of the Christian Bible from the original languages, including a translation of the Tanakh or Old Testament from Hebrew into English. This became known as the [[King James Version of the Bible]], often referred to today by the abbreviation "KJV." Even so, many KJV Old Testament names were not entirely without New Testament Greek influence. This influence mostly reflected the vowels of names, leaving most of the consonants largely intact, only modestly filtered to consonants of contemporary English phonology. However, all KJV names followed the Greek convention of not distinguishing between soft and ''dāḡeš'' forms of ב ''bêṯ''. These habits resulted in multilingually fused Hebræo-Helleno-English names, such as [[Judah (son of Jacob)|Judah]], [[Isaiah]] and [[Jeremiah]]. Additionally, a handful of names were adapted directly from Greek without even partial translations from Hebrew, including names such as [[Isaac]], [[Moses]] and [[Jesse]]. Along with names from the KJV edition of the New Testament, these names constitute the large part of Hebrew names as they exist in the English-speaking world. ==See also== *[[Christian name]] *[[Arabic name]] *[[List of Hebrew place names]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Hebrew_given_names List of Hebrew names at Wiktionary] * [http://blog.judaicawebstore.com/most-popular-american-womens-names-in-hebrew-transliterated-phonetically/ Most Popular American Women’s Names In Hebrew (Phonetic Transliteration)] * [http://www.chabad.org/library/article.asp?AID=260662 Customs relating to the naming of a child] from the Chabad group of Hassidic Judaism * {{CathEncy|wstitle=Christian Names}} – article on old testament naming from a Catholic perspective * [http://www.allhebrewnames.com List of over 2500 Hebrew names used in Israel with pronunciation] * [http://www.shemli.co.il List of all first names used in Israel with pronunciation and statistics in Hebrew] * [http://eteacherhebrew.com/hebrew-names A list of all modern Hebrew names and their meaning] * [http://www.baby-names.co.il/ List of all Hebrew first names used in Israel, all Hebrew Names For Boys & Girls ( 2016 Update ) ] * [http://www.bebelereisim.com/koken/ibranice Names from Hebrew to Turkish]

{{POV|date=July 2017|Flag this article!}} {{Infobox person | name = José Jaime Maussan Flota | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1953|05|31}} | birth_place = [[Mexico City]], Mexico | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | residence = | education = [[National Autonomous University of Mexico]]
[[Miami University]] | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Journalist]] | organization = | website = | footnotes = }} '''José Jaime Maussan Flota''' (born May 31, 1953) is a [[Mexico|Mexican]] [[journalist]], television personality and [[Ufology|ufologist]].{{cite book |title=US/Mexico Business |year=1997 |publisher=Hemisphere Publishers' Group |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8cG2AAAAIAAJ&q=%22Jaime+Maussan%22&dq=%22Jaime+Maussan%22&num=100&pgis=1 |accessdate=2008-10-02}}http://www.miamialum.org/s/916/16/interior.aspx?sid=916&gid=1&page_id=61&pgid=253&cid=645&ecid=21703&search=Jaime%20Maussan == Career == Jaime Maussan studied journalism at [[UNAM]] and [[Miami University]] in [[Ohio]], [[United States]]. Since 1970 he has been a reporter at various newspapers and broadcasting outlets, among them [[Organización Editorial Mexicana|El Sol de México]], [[XEX-AM|XEX Radio]] and with [[Televisa]], he worked at 24 Horas newscast. With Televisa he was a correspondent at the United States and a general assignment reporter for the ''Domingo a Domingo'' (Sunday to Sunday) program hosted by [[Jacobo Zabludovsky]]. He also produced stories for the Sunday show. In June 1990 he received a Global 500 award from [[Mostafa Kamal Tolba]] Executive Director of the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP).http://www.global500.org/index.php/thelaureates/online-directory/item/449-jose-jaime-flota In 1991 Jaime Maussan broke records at Mexican Television next to [[Nino Canun]] and his program ''Y usted que opina?'', since they transmitted for over 11 hours and a half on the subject of UFOs.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} Maussan, in June 2017, was involved in the analysis of 5 [[mummies]] discovered in [[Peru]] at the region where the UNESCO World Heritage [[Nazca Lines]] site is located. The images of these findings were initially aired in a documentary sponsored by [[Gaia, Inc.]] and it allegedly shows a crouched mummified body of a humanoid figure with an elongated skull and three fingers on each hand and foot.) == Education == * [[National Autonomous University of Mexico]] (1972–73) * Graduated from [[Miami University]] with a B.A. in Radio and Television (1974–1976). ==Controversy== [[Snopes]] reported that Maussan "led an event called Be Witness, at which a mummified body — purportedly that of an alien — was unveiled. Later, though, that 'alien' discovery was debunked. The mummified corpse was shown to be that of a human child.".http://www.snopes.com/alien-mummy-peru/ == References == {{BLP sources|date=February 2008}} {{Reflist}} {{Refbegin}} * {{Cite web | last =Sainz | first =Pablo Jaime | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =He sees Maya link in UFOs, natural disasters | work = | publisher =[[Sign On San Diego]] | date =November 10, 2005 | url =http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/features/20051110-9999-1c10ufo.html | doi = | accessdate =2007-04-17}} * {{Cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Mexico pilots release 'UFO film' | work = | publisher =[[BBC News]] | date =May 12, 2004 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/3707057.stm | format = | doi = | accessdate =2007-04-17}} * {{Cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Expert: Mexico UFOs May Have Been Gas | work = | publisher =[[Fox News]] | date =May 17, 2004 | url =http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,120193,00.html | doi = | accessdate =2007-04-17}} * {{Cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Mexican Air Force pilots film unidentified flying objects | work = | publisher =Sign On San Diego | date = May 11, 2004 | url =http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/mexico/20040511-1438-mexico-military-ufos.html | doi = | accessdate =2007-04-17}} * {{Cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Mexican Air Force Shoots UFO| work =| publisher =BakuToday| date =July 12, 2004| url =http://www.bakutoday.net/view.php?d=9061| format =| doi =| accessdate =2007-04-17| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20071121194405/http://www.bakutoday.net/view.php?d=9061| archivedate =November 21, 2007| df =}} * {{Cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Is this deformed mummy ‘discovered’ in Peru for real? | work = | publisher =NYTimes | date = June 23, 2017 | url =https://nypost.com/2017/06/23/is-this-deformed-mummy-discovered-in-peru-for-real/ | format = | doi = | accessdate =2017-07-17}} {{Refend}} == External links == *{{es icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20070126070807/http://ovnis.tv/index.html Jaime Maussan - Homepage] *{{es icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20070206035541/http://ovnis.tv/2006/archivos/Directoriostaff.html Jaime Maussan - Homepage - Biography] *{{en icon}} [http://www.ufowatchdog.com/jamie_maussan.htm Jaime Maussan - The Essence] * {{IMDb name|1481808}} === Videos === * [http://safespaceproject.com/ Safespace] - [http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=4134340386569848505 Fastwalkers] - Winter 2006 * [http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=7310660742580339958&q=jamie+ufo&hl=en UFO Conference] - 2005 {{UFOs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Maussan, Jaime}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:National Autonomous University of Mexico alumni]] [[Category:Mexican journalists]] [[Category:Male journalists]] [[Category:Ufologists]] [[Category:UFO writers]] [[Category:Miami University alumni]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]]
