{{use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox royalty | name = الأمير مولاي هشام بن عبد الله‎
Moulay Hicham ben Abdallah Alaoui |title =Prince of Morocco | image = Prince Moulay Hicham.jpg | image_size = 230px | alt = | caption = Prince Moulay Hicham pictured before a court in [[Casablanca]] | succession = | spouse = Malika Benabdelali | spouse-type = Spouse | consort = | issue = ''Sharifa Lalla'' Faizah Alaoui
''Sharifa Lalla'' Haajar Alaoui | issue-link = | issue-pipe = | full name = Hicham ben Abdallah Alaoui | era name = | era dates = | posthumous name = | temple name = | royal house = [[Alaouite dynasty|Alaouite]] | house-type = Dynasty | father = [[Prince Moulay Abdallah of Morocco|Prince Moulay Abdallah]] | mother = ''Lalla'' Lamia Solh | Daughter = Sherifa Lalla Faizah Alaoui and Sherifa Lalla Haajar Alaoui | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|3|04|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Rabat]], [[Morocco]] | death_date = | death_place = | burial_date = | burial_place = | occupation = | signature = | religion = [[Sunni Islam]] }} {{Moroccan Royal Family}} '''Prince Moulay Hicham of Morocco''' ({{lang-ar|الأمير مولاي هشام بن عبد الله}}, born 4 March 1964) is the first cousin of the current [[King Mohammed VI]] and [[Prince Moulay Rachid]]. He is the son of [[Prince Moulay Abdallah of Morocco]], the late brother of former King [[Hassan II of Morocco|Hassan II]], and Princess Lalla Lamia Solh, daughter of [[Riad Al Solh]], the first [[Prime minister of Lebanon]]. He is also the cousin of Prince [[Al-Waleed bin Talal]] of [[Saudi Arabia]], whose mother Mona Al Solh is another daughter of the Lebanese family. Under the Moroccan constitution, Moulay Hicham stands fourth in the [[Line of succession to the Moroccan throne|line of succession]] to the [[Alaouite dynasty|Alaouite throne]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.royalark.net/Morocco/morocco12.htm|title=MOROCCO12|website=www.royalark.net|access-date=2018-02-24}} In his youth, Prince Moulay Hicham garnered the nickname "Red Prince" because of his [[progressivism|progressive]] political positions. More recently, he has become an outspoken advocate for greater democracy in [[Morocco]]{{Cite web|url=http://fsi.stanford.edu/news/3243|title=Stanford WebLogin|website=fsi.stanford.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-02-24}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2012/08/28/the-staying-power-of-arab-monarchies|title=The Staying Power of Arab Monarchies|language=en|access-date=2018-02-24}} and the broader Middle East.{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yXOSP1WxNm0|title=YouTube|website=www.youtube.com|language=en|access-date=2018-02-24}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110217-en-interview-prince-moulay-hicham-el-alaoui-mohammed-vi-morocco-democracy-transition-stanford-fellow/|title=Prince Moulay Hicham El Alaoui of Morocco, cousin of King Mohammed VI - France 24|date=2011-02-17|work=France 24|access-date=2018-02-24|language=en-US}} He regularly speaks on these issues at public forums around the world, among them the [[University of Málaga]],{{Citation|last=Fundación General de la Universidad de Málaga|title=Conferencia del Príncipe Moulay Hicham en la UMA (Ponencia 1/5)|date=2011-07-16|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bg-jYUbM_gA|accessdate=2018-02-24}} [[HEC Paris]],{{Citation|last=HECMondeArabe|title=Conférence inaugurale d'HECMA avec Moulay Hicham Partie 1|date=2012-02-03|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OAO5DViBnRA|accessdate=2018-02-24}} [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign]],{{Cite web|url=http://newmiddleeast.csames.illinois.edu/program/speakers/|title=Conference on the New Middle East|website=newmiddleeast.csames.illinois.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-02-24}} [[Harvard University]],{{Citation|last=Harvard Arab Alumni Association|title=Harvard Arab Weekend 2013 {{!}} Prince Moulay Hicham Keynote {{!}} Harvard Law School - November 7, 2013|date=2013-12-10|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dQjGMBnkDs0|accessdate=2018-02-24}} and [[Yale University]].{{Cite news|url=https://news.yale.edu/2016/04/05/moroccan-prince-deliver-coca-cola-world-fund-lecture-yale|title=Moroccan prince to deliver the Coca-Cola World Fund Lecture at Yale|date=2016-04-05|work=YaleNews|access-date=2018-02-24|language=en}} He has also published numerous essays on political reform and democracy in English, French, and Arabic language journals and newspapers.{{Cite web|url=http://www.journalofdemocracy.org/article/split-arab-culture|title=The Split in Arab Culture {{!}} Journal of Democracy|website=www.journalofdemocracy.org|language=en|access-date=2018-02-24}}{{Cite news|url=http://mondediplo.com/2013/01/02arabspring|title=Are the Arab monarchies next?|date=2013-01-01|work=Le Monde diplomatique|access-date=2018-02-24|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.revue-pouvoirs.fr/L-autre-Maroc.html|title=L’autre Maroc - Hicham BEN ABDALLAH EL ALAOUI - Pouvoirs, revue française d’études constitutionnelles et politiques|last=ALAOUI|first=Hicham BEN ABDALLAH EL|website=www.revue-pouvoirs.fr|access-date=2018-02-24}} He was most recently a consulting professor at the [[Stanford University centers and institutes#Freeman Spogli Institute for International Studies|Center for Democracy, Development, and Rule of Law]] at [[Stanford University]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.stanforddaily.com/2012/01/11/professor-prince/|title=Professor, prince|work=Stanford Daily|access-date=2018-02-24|language=en-US}}[http://fsi.stanford.edu/people/hichamben+abdallah Faculty Profile] He is currently based at [[Harvard University]].[https://wcfia.harvard.edu/people/hicham-alaoui Hicham Alaoui Profile at Weatherhead Center] ==Professional Activities== *Founder and President of the [[Hicham Alaoui Foundation]], a non-profit private foundation that has supported social science research on the Arab world at leading universities.{{Cite web|url=http://moulayhichamfoundation.org/|title=Accueil {{!}} MOULAY HICHAM FOUNDATION|website=moulayhichamfoundation.org|language=en|access-date=2018-02-24}} *Co-founder, along with [[John Waterbury]] and Abdellah Hammoudi, of the Institute for the Transregional Study of the Contemporary Middle East, North Africa and Central Asia (TRI) at [[Princeton University]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.princeton.edu/transregional/|title=The Institute for the Transregional Study of the Contemporary Middle East, North Africa and Central Asia - Home|last=University|first=Princeton|website=www.princeton.edu|access-date=2018-02-24}} *Advisory Board Member of the Middle East program of the [[Carnegie Endowment for International Peace]].{{Cite news|url=http://carnegie-mec.org/about/|title=عن صدى|work=Carnegie Middle East Center|access-date=2018-02-24|language=ar}} *Producer of the 2012 award-winning documentary on democratization and dictatorship, [[A Whisper to a Roar]], in collaboration with director [[Ben Moses]].{{Cite web|url=http://awhispertoaroar.com/|title=A WHISPER TO A ROAR {{!}} They will be heard|website=awhispertoaroar.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-24}} *Numerous past advisory positions for democracy NGOs, including [[Human Rights Watch]] and the [[Carter Center]]. ==Personal life== As a member of the Moroccan royal family, Prince Moulay Hicham was raised in the palace quarter of [[Rabat]] alongside his brother and cousins, including the current [[King Mohammed VI]]. He attended the [[Rabat American School]] and graduated from [[Princeton University]] in 1985.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyprincetonian.com/2006/12/04/16833/|title=The Princetonian|work=The Princetonian|access-date=2018-02-24}} He later attended [[Stanford|Stanford University]] for graduate study in political science. Many of these events are outlined in his memoirs, ''Journal d'un Prince Banni,''{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.fr/Journal-dun-prince-banni-Demain/dp/2246851653|title=Journal d'un prince banni: Demain, le Maroc|last=Alaoui|first=Moulay Hicham el|date=2014-04-09|publisher=Grasset|isbn=9782246851653|location=Paris}} published in April 2014 to considerable controversy.{{Citation|last=FRANCE 24 English|title=Moulay Hicham El Alaoui, Morocco's 'rebel prince'|date=2014-04-09|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sCl8HiTPkLU|accessdate=2018-02-24}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2014/03/126993/france-french-man-arrested-for-stalking-prince-moulay-hicham/|title=France: French Man Arrested for Stalking Prince Moulay Hicham|date=2014-03-31|work=Morocco World News|access-date=2018-02-24|language=en-US}} In 2002, Prince Moulay Hicham relocated to [[Princeton, New Jersey]] with his family.{{Cite web|url=http://www.telquel-online.com/archives/452/images/Moulay%20Hicham.pdf|title=Telquel Online - Online Financial Industry|website=Telquel Online|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-24}} He is married since 1995 to Sharifa Lalla Malika Benabdelali, a cousin of the Moroccan businessman and longtime Minister of Agriculture [[Aziz Akhannouch]]. He has two daughters: Sharifa Lalla Faizah Alaoui (born 1996) who attended [[Yale University]], and Sharifa Lalla Haajar Alaoui (born 1999) who attends [[Princeton University]]. He is currently pursuing a D.Phil. in Middle East studies at the [[University of Oxford]]. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://moulayhicham.com Moulay Hicham Selected Writings (Official Website)] * [http://moulayhichamfoundation.org Moulay Hicham Foundation for Social Research on North Africa and the Middle East] {{s-start}} {{s-roy}} {{s-bef|before=[[Prince Moulay Rachid of Morocco|Prince Moulay Rachid]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Line of succession to the Moroccan Throne]]}} {{s-after|after=[[Prince Moulay Ismail of Morocco]]|as=Prince Moulay Ismail}} {{end}} {{Mohammed VI}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Moulay Hicham}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Arabs]] [[Category:Moroccan people of Lebanese descent]] [[Category:Moroccan people of Arab descent]] [[Category:Moroccan royalty]] [[Category:Moroccan princes]] [[Category:Alumni of Rabat American School]] [[Category:Stanford University faculty]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:Arab Moroccans]] [[Category:Moroccan academics]] [[Category:Moroccan businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Rabat]]

revision.text:
{{short description|American politician}} {{for|people with similar names|Richard Perry (disambiguation)|James Perry (disambiguation){{!}}James Perry}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Rick Perry |image = Rick Perry official portrait.jpg |office = 14th [[United States Secretary of Energy]] |president = [[Donald Trump]] |deputy = [[Dan Brouillette]] |term_start = March 2, 2017 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Ernest Moniz]] |successor = |order1 = 47th [[Governor of Texas]] |lieutenant1 = [[Bill Ratliff]]
[[David Dewhurst]] |term_start1 = December 21, 2000 |term_end1 = January 20, 2015 |predecessor1 = [[George W. Bush]] |successor1 = [[Greg Abbott]] |office2 = 39th [[Lieutenant Governor of Texas]] |governor2 = George W. Bush |term_start2 = January 19, 1999 |term_end2 = December 21, 2000 |predecessor2 = [[Bob Bullock]] |successor2 = Bill Ratliff |office3 = 9th [[Texas Department of Agriculture|Agriculture Commissioner of Texas]] |governor3 = [[Ann Richards]]
George W. Bush |term_start3 = January 15, 1991 |term_end3 = January 19, 1999 |predecessor3 = [[Jim Hightower]] |successor3 = [[Susan Combs]] |state_house4 = Texas |district4 = [[Texas House of Representatives, District 64|64th]] |term_start4 = January 8, 1985 |term_end4 = January 8, 1991 |predecessor4 = Joe Hanna |successor4 = John Cook |birth_name = James Richard Perry |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1950|3|4}} |birth_place = [[Haskell, Texas]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] (1989–present) |otherparty = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] (Before 1989) |spouse = {{marriage|[[Anita Thigpen Perry|Anita Thigpen]]|1982}} |children = 2 |education = [[Texas A&M University]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]]) |net_worth = $2 million{{cite news |title=Here's What Each Member Of Trump's $4.5 Billion Cabinet Is Worth |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/chasewithorn/2016/12/22/heres-how-much-trumps-cabinet-is-really-worth/#3b5c6faf7169 |first=Chase |last=Peterson-Withorn |publisher=[[Forbes]] |date=December 22, 2016}} |signature = Rick Perry signature.svg |allegiance = {{flag|United States}} |branch = {{air force|United States}} |serviceyears = 1972–1977{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/102485251#. |title=Captain Rick Perry: Time for a military man in the White House? |last=Kudlow |first=Larry |date=March 6, 2015 |publisher=[[CNBC]] |accessdate=September 13, 2016}} |rank = [[File:US-O3 insignia.svg|18px]] [[Captain (United States O-3)|Captain]] |unit = 772nd Tactical Airlift Squadron }} {{Rick Perry series}} '''James Richard "Rick" Perry''' (born March 4, 1950) is an American politician who is the 14th and current [[United States Secretary of Energy]], serving in the [[Cabinet of Donald Trump]]. Prior to his cabinet position, Perry served as the [[List of Governors of Texas|47th]] [[Governor of Texas]] from December 2000 to January 2015. A [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], he was elected [[Lieutenant Governor of Texas]] in 1998 and assumed the governorship in December 2000 when Governor [[George W. Bush]] resigned to become president. Perry was the longest-serving Governor in Texas history. Perry was elected three times to full gubernatorial terms and is the fourth Texas Governor (after [[Allan Shivers]], [[Price Daniel]] and [[John Connally]]) to serve three terms. With a tenure in office of 14 years, 30 days, Perry was, at the time he left office, the second longest-serving current governor (after [[Terry Branstad]] of Iowa). Perry ran unsuccessfully for the Republican nomination for president in [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012]] and [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016]]. On December 14, 2016, President-elect [[Donald Trump]] announced his intention to nominate Perry as his [[United States Secretary of Energy|Secretary of Energy]]. On March 2, 2017, he was confirmed by the United States Senate in a 62–37 vote.{{Cite news|url=https://decisiondeskhq.com/vote-tracker/confirmation-vote-of-rick-perry-for-secretary-of-energy/|title=Confirmation Vote of Rick Perry for Secretary of Energy {{!}} Decision Desk HQ|date=March 2, 2017|work=Decision Desk HQ|access-date=March 2, 2017|language=en-US}} ==Early life== A fifth-generation Texan, he was born on March 4, 1950, in [[Haskell, Texas]], and raised in [[Paint Creek, Texas]], the son of [[Dryland farming|dryland]] cotton farmers Joseph Ray Perry and Amelia June Holt Perry. He has one older sister. Perry's ancestry is almost entirely English, dating as far back as the original [[Thirteen Colonies]]. His family has been in Texas since before the [[Texas Revolution]].{{cite web|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/celeb/perry.htm|title=rick perry|publisher=Freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com|accessdate=March 12, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.surnamedb.com/Surname/Perry|title=Surname Database: Perry Last Name Origin|publisher=Surnamedb.com|accessdate=March 12, 2012}} His father, a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], was a long-time Haskell County commissioner and [[school board]] member. Perry has said that his interest in politics probably began in November 1961, when his father took him to the funeral of U.S. Representative [[Sam Rayburn]].{{cite news|title=Richard L. Connor: Texas’ Perry might surprise Obama in 2012|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2011/06/05/texas-perry-might-surprise-obama-in-2012_2011-06-05/|accessdate=January 4, 2017|publisher=Portland Press Herald|date=June 5, 2011}} Perry was in the [[Boy Scouts of America|Boy Scouts]] (BSA) and earned the rank of [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]].{{cite web|url=http://www.governor.state.tx.us/about|title=Texas Governor Rick Perry|publisher=Office of the Governor|accessdate=November 8, 2006}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cnsnews.com/ViewCulture.asp?Page=/Culture/archive/200802/CUL20080211b.html|title=Texas Governor Urges Protection for Boy Scouts of America|last=Lucas|first=Fred|publisher=[[Cybercast News Service]]|date=February 11, 2008|archivedate=May 18, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518183709/http://www.cnsnews.com/ViewCulture.asp?Page=%2FCulture%2Farchive%2F200802%2FCUL20080211b.html|accessdate=August 12, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}} The BSA has honored Perry with the [[Distinguished Eagle Scout Award]].{{cite web|url=http://www.scouting.org/filestore/pdf/02-529.pdf|title=Distinguished Eagle Scout Award|publisher=[[Boy Scouts of America]]|accessdate=November 4, 2010}} Perry graduated from [[Paint Creek Independent School District|Paint Creek High School]] in 1968. ===College=== Perry attended [[Texas A&M University]] where he was a member of the [[Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets|Corps of Cadets]] and the [[Alpha Gamma Rho]] fraternity. He was elected senior class social secretary, a member and [[Aggie bonfire leadership|'''redpot''']] in [[Aggie Bonfire]], and one of A&M's five [[Aggie Yell Leaders|"yell leaders"]].{{cite news|last=Hylton|first=Hilary|url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1873143,00.html|title=Bush Returns to a Divided Texas Republican Party|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=January 25, 2009}}[http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/cheerleading-politics/story?id=16380524#5 From Cheerleading to Politics], Abcnews.go.com (May 19, 2012); retrieved September 13, 2016. He graduated in 1972 with a Bachelor of Science degree in animal science.{{cite news|last=Hooks|first=Chris|url=http://www.texastribune.org/texas-people/rick-perry/perry-aggie-years|title=Texas A&M Years Launched Perry – and a Rivalry|work=[[The Texas Tribune]]|location=Austin|date=August 2, 2011|accessdate=August 7, 2011}}{{Cite news|title=Trivia question: Which presidential candidate has a degree in economics?|url=http://caucuses.desmoinesregister.com/2011/09/21/trivia-question-which-presidential-candidate-has-a-degree-in-economics/|date=September 21, 2011|first=Jennifer|last=Jacobs|work=[[The Des Moines Register]]|accessdate=November 12, 2011}} In 1989, he said that "I was probably a bit of a free spirit, not particularly structured real well for life outside of a military regime, I would have not lasted at [[Texas Tech University|Texas Tech]] or the [[University of Texas]]. I would have hit the fraternity scene and lasted about one semester." ===First jobs=== In the early 1970s, Perry interned during several summers with [[Southwestern Advantage]], as a [[Door-to-door salesman|door-to-door book salesman]]. "I count my time working for Dortch Oldham [then president of the [[Southwestern family of companies]]] as one of the most important formative experiences of my life", Perry said in 2010. "There is nothing that tests your commitment to a goal like getting a few doors closed in your face." He said that "Mr. Oldham taught legions of young people to communicate quickly, clearly and with passion, a lesson that has served me well in my life since then."{{cite news |url=http://www.nashvillepost.com/news/2009/2/27/dortch_oldham_dies_at_89 |title=Dortch Oldham dies at 89 |accessdate=December 2, 2010 |last=Wood |first=E. Thomas |date=February 27, 2009 |publisher=[[NashvillePost.com]]}} Upon graduation from college in 1972, Perry was commissioned as an officer in the [[United States Air Force]] and completed pilot training in February 1974. He was then assigned as a [[C-130]] pilot with the 772nd Tactical Airlift Squadron at [[Dyess Air Force Base, located in Abilene, Texas]]. Perry's duties included two-month overseas rotations at [[RAF Mildenhall]], located in [[Mildenhall, Suffolk|Mildenhall]], England and [[Rhein-Main Air Base]], located at Frankfurt am Main, Germany. His missions included a 1974 [[U.S. State Department]] drought relief effort in [[Mali]], [[Mauritania]] and [[Chad]], and two years later, earthquake relief in Guatemala.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/26/us/politics/for-rick-perry-air-force-service-broadened-and-narrowed-life.html?pagewanted=all | work=The New York Times | title=For Rick Perry, Air Force Service Broadened and Narrowed Life | date=November 25, 2011}} He left the [[United States Air Force]] in 1977 with the rank of [[Captain (United States O-3)|Captain]], returned to Texas, and went into business farming cotton with his father.{{cite web |url=http://www.usglc.org/2011/08/12/rick-perry/ |title=Candidates' Corner 2012– Rick Perry |publisher=U.S. Global Leadership Coalition | American Foreign Policy & Foreign Affairs – Usglc.org |date=August 13, 2011 |accessdate=August 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120514054016/http://www.usglc.org/2011/08/12/rick-perry/ |archivedate=May 14, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} ==Early political career== [[File:Bush Contact Sheet P17939 (cropped2).jpg|thumb|right|Perry with [[President of the United States|President]] [[George H. W. Bush]] in 1990]] === Texas Legislature === In 1984, Perry was elected to the [[Texas House of Representatives]] as a Democrat from district 64, which included his home county of [[Haskell County, Texas|Haskell]]. He served on the House Appropriations and Calendars committees during his three two-year terms in office. He befriended fellow freshman state representative [[Lena Guerrero]], a staunch liberal Democrat who endorsed Perry's reelection bid in 2006. Perry was part of the "Pit Bulls", a group of Appropriations members who sat on the lower dais in the committee room (or "pit") who pushed for austere state budgets during the 1980s.{{cite news |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/onpolitics/post/2011/07/rick-perry-presidential-race-former-democrat/1 |title=GOP's Rick Perry spent early years as a Democrat |first=Catalina |last=Camia |work=USA Today |date=July 15, 2011 |accessdate=August 18, 2011}} At one point, ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' named him one of the ten most effective members of the legislature.{{cite web |title=71st Legislature, 6th C.S., HR63. |url=http://www.lrl.state.tx.us/scanned/members/honorary/71/Perry_Rick_HR63.pdf |year=1990 |publisher=Legislative Reference Library of Texas |accessdate=August 13, 2011}} In 1987, Perry voted for a $5.7 billion tax increase proposed by Republican governor [[Bill Clements]].Jay Root, [http://www.texastribune.org/texas-politics/2012-presidential-election/rick-perry-democrat-years/ Rick Perry: The Democrat Years] ''[[The Texas Tribune]]'' July 14, 2011. Perry supported [[Al Gore]] in the 1988 Democratic presidential primaries and worked for Gore's campaign in Texas.{{cite web | title = Rick Perry backed Al Gore, didn't lead his Texas campaign | last = Selby | first = W. Gardner | work = PolitiFact Texas | date = September 7, 2011 | accessdate = June 4, 2015 | url = http://www.politifact.com/texas/article/2011/sep/07/perry-backed-gore-did-not-lead-his-texas-campaign/ | quote = }} On September 29, 1989, Perry announced that he was switching parties, becoming a Republican.[https://web.archive.org/web/20100223160631/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/politics/state/stories/022110dnpol50thingsperry.1320b32fa.html "50 Things You need to Know about Governor Rick Perry"] ''Dallas Morning News'' February 19, 2010. === Agriculture Commissioner === In 1990, as a newly minted Republican, Perry challenged [[Jim Hightower]], the incumbent Democratic [[Texas Agriculture Commissioner|Agriculture Commissioner]]. [[Karl Rove]] was Perry's campaign manager.{{cite book|last1=Bickerstaff|first1=Steve|title=Lines in the Sand: Congressional Redistricting in Texas and the Downfall of Tom DeLay|date=2010|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=9780292783058|page=21}} In the Republican primary on March 13, 1990, Perry polled 276,558 votes (47%), with [[Richard McIver]] garnering 176,976 votes (30%) and Gene L. Duke, who placed third, polling 132,497 votes (23%).{{cite web |url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=783049|title=TX Agriculture Commissioner – R Primary Race – Mar 13, 1990|work=Our Campaigns|accessdate=February 4, 2016}} Since Perry fell shy of the necessary 50% to win outright, a runoff was held between Perry and McIver set on April 10, 1990. In the runoff, he emerged victorious, garnering 96,649 votes (69%) to McIver's 43,921 votes (31%).{{cite web |url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=783050|title=TX Agriculture Commissioner – R Runoff Race |date=April 10, 1990|work=Our Campaigns|accessdate=February 4, 2016}} During 1990, Hightower's office was embroiled in an FBI investigation into corruption and bribery. Three aides were convicted in 1993 of using public funds for political fundraising, although Hightower himself was not found to be involved in the wrongdoings.[https://web.archive.org/web/20120302061411/http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/1993_1166833/three-ex-aides-to-hightower-are-sentenced.html Three ex-aides to Hightower are sentenced] [[Houston Chronicle]]. November 11, 1993 Perry narrowly defeated Hightower in November 1990, garnering 1,864,463 votes (49%) to Hightower's 1,820,145 votes (48%).{{cite web |url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=309970 |title=TX Agriculture Commissioner Race |date=November 6, 1990 |publisher=Our Campaigns|accessdate=February 4, 2016}} Rove raised $3 million to raise Perry's profile, "while tarnishing the name of Jim Hightower" resulting in Perry's name becoming a "household name in Texas—and Hightower's name synonymous with corruption".{{cite book|author1=Lou Dubose|author2=Jan Reid|author3=Carl M. Cannon|title=Boy Genius: Karl Rove, the Brains Behind the Remarkable Political Triumph of George W. Bush|date=2003|publisher=PublicAffairs|isbn=9781586481926|page=43}} As Agriculture Commissioner, Perry was responsible for promoting the sale of Texas farm produce to other states and foreign nations, and for supervising the calibration of weights and measures, such as [[gasoline]] pumps and [[grocery store]] scales.{{cite web |url=http://www.agr.state.tx.us/agr/main_render/0,1968,1848_8330_0_0,00.html?channelId=8330 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060822090027/http://www.agr.state.tx.us/agr/main_render/0%2C1968%2C1848_8330_0_0%2C00.html?channelId=8330 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 22, 2006 |title=What is the Texas Department of Agriculture? |publisher=Texas Department of Agriculture |accessdate=August 18, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} In April 1993, Perry, while serving as Texas agriculture commissioner, expressed support for the effort [[Health care reform in the United States|to reform]] the nation's healthcare, describing it as "most commendable".{{cite news|url=http://www.politifact.com/texas/statements/2011/sep/24/ron-paul/ron-paul-says-rick-perry-wrote-letter-supporting-h/|title=Ron Paul says Rick Perry wrote a letter supporting Hillarycare|date=September 24, 2011|work=[[Austin American-Statesman]] / [[PolitiFact.com]]|accessdate=October 18, 2011|first=Meghan|last=Ashford-Grooms}} The healthcare plan, first revealed in September, was ultimately [[Clinton health care plan of 1993#Defeat|unsuccessful]] due to Republican congressional opposition.{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/Perry-letter-commending-Hillary-Clinton-found-1914428.phpa|title=Perry letter commending Hillary Clinton found|date=March 29, 2005|work=Houston Chronicle|author=R.G. Ratcliffe}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aim.org/newswire/tea-party-faithful-wonder-if-rick-perry-walks-the-walk/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111101210038/http://www.aim.org/newswire/tea-party-faithful-wonder-if-rick-perry-walks-the-walk/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=November 1, 2011 |title=Tea Party faithful wonder if Rick Perry walks the walk |publisher=[[Accuracy in Media]]|date=August 10, 2011|accessdate=October 10, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.texastribune.org/texas-politics/2012-presidential-election/perry-social-conservatives-and-the-road-to-the-top/|title=Perry, Social Conservatives and the Road to the Top|date=July 14, 2011 |first=Ross|last=Ramsey |work=The Texas Tribune }}{{cite news |url=http://blog.mysanantonio.com/texas-politics/2009/09/the-video-perrys-campaign-cant-resist-using/ |title=The video Perry's campaign can't resist using |date=September 10, 2009 |first=R.G.|last=Ratcliffe |work=San Antonio Express-News}}Mark, David. [https://books.google.com/books?id=FVsLGFxrMDIC&pg=PA123&lpg=PA123&dq=perry+clinton+%22health+care%22+commendable&source=bl&ots=GvDfvHl-R0&sig=MJ6bTHIaoXKI4jjTl5tDWaMRnJE&hl=en&ei=bi5cTpOxCoq1sQL9p7EV&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFEQ6AEwCDgU#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Going dirty: the Art of Negative Campaigning'']. p. 127. In 2005, after being questioned on the issue by a potential opponent in the Republican governor primary, Perry said that he expressed his support only in order to get Clinton to pay more attention to rural healthcare.{{cite news |url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/Perry-says-Hutchison-Clinton-video-politics-as-1660157.php|title=Perry says Hutchison-Clinton video politics as usual |date=March 30, 2005 |work=Houston Chronicle |first=R.G.|last=Ratcliffe}} In 1994, Perry was reelected Agriculture Commissioner by a large margin, getting 2,546,287 votes (62 percent) to Democrat Marvin Gregory's 1,479,692 (36 percent). [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian]] Clyde L. Garland received the remaining 85,836 votes (2 percent).{{cite web |url=http://elections.sos.state.tx.us/ |title=Office of the Secretary of State : 1992 – Current ELECTION HISTORY |publisher=Elections.oso.state.tx.us |accessdate=May 5, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815140750/http://elections.sos.state.tx.us/ |archive-date=August 15, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} Gregory, a chicken farmer from [[Sulphur Springs, Texas]], was on the Texas Agricultural Finance Authority with Perry in the early nineties as a Republican, but became a Democrat before running against Perry in 1994.{{cite news |work=Texas Monthly |date=September 2011|url=http://www.texasmonthly.com/2011-09-01/feature7.php|title=The Great Campaigner|first=Mimi|last=Swartz}} ===Lieutenant Governor=== In 1998, Perry ran for the powerful job of [[Lieutenant Governor of Texas|Lieutenant Governor]]. During this election, Perry had a notable falling out with his previous top political strategist Karl Rove, which began the much-reported rivalry between the [[George W. Bush|Bush]] and Perry camps.{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0711/59687.html|work=Politico|title=If Rick Perry gets in, will Karl Rove be out?|accessdate=September 10, 2010}} Perry polled 1,858,837 votes (50.04 percent) to the 1,790,106 (48.19 percent) cast for Democrat [[John Sharp (Texas politician)|John Sharp]]. Perry became the state's [[List of lieutenant governors of Texas|first Republican lieutenant governor since Reconstruction]], taking office on January 19, 1999. == Governor of Texas == {{main|Governorship of Rick Perry}} [[File:FEMA - 16240 - Photograph by Ed Edahl taken on 09-27-2005 in Texas.jpg|left|thumb|President George W. Bush and Texas Governor Rick Perry shake hands September 27, 2005, after a question-and-answer session at the Port Arthur airport. Port Arthur suffered extensive damage from Hurricane Rita.]] Perry assumed the office of governor on December 21, 2000, following the resignation of [[George W. Bush]]—who was preparing to become [[President of the United States]]. He won the office in his own right in the [[Texas gubernatorial election, 2002|2002 gubernatorial election]], where he received 58% of votes to Laredo oilman and businessman [[Tony Sanchez (politician)|Tony Sanchez]]'s 40%. He was re-elected in the [[Texas gubernatorial election, 2006|2006 gubernatorial election]] against three major opponents, polling 39% of votes against runner-up former U.S. Congressman [[Chris Bell (politician)|Chris Bell]] of Houston with 30%. In the [[Texas gubernatorial election, 2010|2010 gubernatorial election]], Perry became the first Texas governor to be elected to three four-year terms, polling 55% of votes to former Houston Mayor [[Bill White (Texas politician)|Bill White]]'s 42%. According to [[Texans for Public Justice]], in his three gubernatorial campaigns, Perry received hard-money campaign contributions of $102 million, half of which came from 204 donors.{{Citation | last = Taibbi | first = Matt | author-link = Matt Taibbi | title = Rick Perry: The Best Little Whore In Texas| newspaper = [[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]] | date = October 26, 2011| url = https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/rick-perry-the-best-little-whore-in-texas-20111026?page=3 | accessdate = November 20, 2011}} In the 2001 legislative session, Perry set a record for his use of the [[veto]], rejecting 82 acts, more than any other governor in any single legislative session in the history of the state since [[Reconstruction era of the United States|Reconstruction]].[http://texaspolitics.laits.utexas.edu/1_4_2.html "The Executive Branch: Budgetary Powers"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223083855/http://texaspolitics.laits.utexas.edu/1_4_2.html |date=February 23, 2014 }}, ''Texas Politics'', [[University of Texas at Austin]], retrieved June 20, 2011[http://texaspolitics.laits.utexas.edu/1_5_2.html The Limits of the Veto] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140228182445/http://texaspolitics.laits.utexas.edu/1_5_2.html |date=February 28, 2014 }}, ''Texas Politics'', [[University of Texas at Austin]], retrieved June 20, 2011{{Cite news|title=Vetoes – Then and Now|url=http://www.texastribune.org/texas-legislature/82nd-legislative-session/on-the-records-vetoes--then-and-now/|date=June 17, 2011|first=Becca|last=Aaronson|work=[[The Texas Tribune]]|location=Austin|postscript=|accessdate=June 20, 2011}} In 2003, Perry formed the [[non-profit organization]], the OneStar Foundation, designed to connect non-profits with resources and expertise to accomplish their missions and to promote [[Volunteering|volunteerism]]. He tapped the state Republican chairman [[Susan Weddington]], who stepped down from that position after six years, as the president of OneStar. She left in 2009, and he chose Elizabeth Seale as her successor.{{cite web |url=http://www.faithworksconference.com/speakers/susanweddington.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090105182452/http://www.faithworksconference.com/speakers/susanweddington.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=January 5, 2009|title=Susan Wedding President/CEO OneStar Foundation|publisher=faithworksconference.com|accessdate=March 19, 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.fundraisingsuccessmag.com/article/san-antonio-exec-named-president-onestar-foundation-403156/1|title=San Antonio Exec Named President of OneStar Foundation|date=February 12, 2009 |work=Fund Raising Success Magazine |access-date=March 19, 2015}} ===Fiscal policies=== In his presidential campaign, Perry highlighted the economic success Texas achieved under his governorship. The efficacy of Perry's economic policies has been questioned by some sources.{{cite news |last=Luhby |first=Tami |url=http://money.cnn.com/2011/08/12/news/economy/perry_texas_jobs/ |title=Rick Perry and his Texas jobs boom: The whole story |publisher=[[CNNMoney.com]] |date=August 12, 2011 |accessdate=August 18, 2011}}{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304259304576375480710070472 |title=The Lone Star Jobs Surge |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=June 10, 2011 |accessdate=August 18, 2011}}{{cite news |last=Plumer |first=Brad |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/ezra-klein/post/breaking-down-rick-perrys-texas-miracle/2011/08/15/gIQAzRHFHJ_blog.html |title=Breaking down Rick Perry's 'Texas miracle' – Ezra Klein |work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=July 28, 2011 |accessdate=August 18, 2011}} A proclaimed proponent of fiscal conservatism, Perry often campaigned on job growth and tax issues, such as his opposition to creating a state [[income tax]]. In 2002, Perry refused to promise not to raise taxes as governor, and in the following years did propose or approve various tax and debt increases.Gleckman, Howard (August 16, 2011). [https://www.forbes.com/sites/beltway/2011/08/16/rick-perrys-changing-take-on-raising-taxes "Rick Perry's Changing Take On Raising Taxes"]. ''[[Forbes]]''; accessed September 13, 2016.[http://www.economist.com/node/10431696 "The Texas pole tax"], ''[[The Economist]]'', January 3, 2008.{{cite pressrelease|url=http://governor.state.tx.us/news/press-release/2426|title=Gov. Perry Signs Landmark Business Tax Reform|publisher=Office of the Governor|date=May 18, 2006|accessdate=August 7, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820081008/http://governor.state.tx.us/news/press-release/2426/|archivedate=August 20, 2011|df=mdy-all}}[https://www.accountingweb.com/aa/law-and-enforcement/new-texas-margin-tax-business-or-income-tax "New Texas Margin Tax – Business or Income Tax"], accountingweb.com, August 16, 2006; retrieved August 18, 2011. In 2009, Perry signed [[Grover Norquist]]'s pledge to "oppose and veto any and all efforts to increase taxes".{{Cite news|url=https://www.atr.org/rick-perry-signs-taxpayer-protection-pledge-american-people|title=Rick Perry Signs Taxpayer Protection Pledge to the American People|newspaper=Americans for Tax Reforms|access-date=January 23, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/aug/12/chris-christie-signs-grover-norquists-no-tax-pledg/|title=Chris Christie signs Grover Norquist’s no-tax pledge|last=http://www.washingtontimes.com|first=The Washington Times|newspaper=The Washington Times|language=en-US|access-date=January 23, 2017}} Texas began borrowing money in 2003 to pay for roads and was projected to owe $17.3 billion by the end of 2012, increasing total state debt from $13.4 billion in 2001 to $37.8 billion in 2011.{{cite news|url=http://blog.chron.com/txpotomac/2011/08/analyzing-rick-perrys-record-texas-transportation-needs-left-behind/ |title=Analyzing Rick Perry's record: Texas transportation needs left behind | Texas on the Potomac|publisher=Blog.chron.com |date=August 20, 2011 |accessdate=March 12, 2012}} The state's public finance authority sold $2 billion in bonds for unemployment benefits, and it was authorized to sell $1.5 billion more if necessary. Texas federal borrowing topped $1.6 billion in October 2010, before the bond sales.{{cite news|last=Schnurman|first=Mitchell|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/2011/07/15/3225103/texas-debt-practices-contradict.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310065746/http://www.star-telegram.com/2011/07/15/3225103/texas-debt-practices-contradict.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=March 10, 2012|title=Texas' debt practices contradict Perry's rhetoric|newspaper=Fort Worth Star-Telegram|accessdate=March 12, 2012}} In 2003, Perry signed legislation that created the [[Texas Enterprise Fund]], which has since given $435 million in grants to businesses. ''The New York Times'' reported that many of the companies receiving grants, or their chief executives, have made contributions to Perry's campaigns or to the Republican Governors Association.[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/21/us/politics/21donate.html Perry Mines Texas System to Raise Cash], by Nicholas Confessore and Michael Lu, ''The New York Times'', August 20, 2011. (Perry became chairman of the group in 2008 and again in 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.rga.org/homepage/rga-announces-new-leadership/ |title=RGA Announces New Leadership |publisher=Republican Governors Association |date=November 18, 2010 |accessdate=March 26, 2011}}) Perry was criticized for supporting corporate tax breaks and other incentives, while the state government was experiencing budget deficits.{{cite news|last=Luhby|first=Tami|url=http://money.cnn.com/2011/01/19/news/economy/texas_budget_deficit/index.htm|title=Even budget deficits are bigger in Texas|publisher=Money.cnn.com|date=January 19, 2011|accessdate=February 22, 2014}}[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/03/us/winners-and-losers-in-texas.html "Lines Blur as Texas Gives Industries a Bonanza"], nytimes.com, December 3, 2012. As Governor of Texas, Perry received grades of B in 2004,{{cite web|last1=Moore|first1=Stephen|last2=Slivinski|first2=Stephen|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://object.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/pubs/pdf/pa537.pdf|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors: 2004|work=Policy Analysis No. 537|date=March 1, 2005|accessdate=September 3, 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Moore|first1=Stephen|last2=Slivinski|first2=Stephen|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://www.cato.org/publications/policy-analysis/fiscal-policy-report-card-americas-governors-2004|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors: 2004|date=March 1, 2005|accessdate=September 3, 2015}} B in 2006,{{cite web|last=Slivinski|first=Stephen|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://object.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/pubs/pdf/pa581.pdf|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors: 2006|work=Policy Analysis No. 581|date=October 24, 2006|accessdate=September 3, 2015}}{{cite web |last=Slivinski|first=Stephen|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://www.cato.org/publications/policy-analysis/fiscal-policy-report-card-americas-governors-2006|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors: 2006|date=October 24, 2006|accessdate=September 3, 2015}} B in 2008,{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=Chris|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://object.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/pubs/pdf/pa-624.pdf|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors: 2008|work=Policy Analysis No. 624|date=October 20, 2008|accessdate=September 3, 2015}}{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=Chris|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://www.cato.org/publications/policy-analysis/fiscal-policy-report-card-americas-governors-2008|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors: 2008|date=October 20, 2008|accessdate=September 3, 2015}} B in 2010,{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=Chris|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://object.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/pubs/pdf/PA668.pdf|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors: 2010|work=Policy Analysis No. 668|date=September 30, 2010|accessdate=September 3, 2015}}{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=Chris|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://www.cato.org/publications/policy-analysis/fiscal-policy-report-card-americas-governors-2010|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors: 2010|date=September 30, 2010|accessdate=September 3, 2015}} C in 2012,{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=Chris|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://object.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/pubs/pdf/GRC2012.pdf|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors 2012|date=October 9, 2012|accessdate=September 3, 2015}}{{cite web |last=Edwards|first=Chris|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://www.cato.org/publications/white-paper/fiscal-policy-report-card-americas-governors-2012|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors: 2012|date=October 9, 2012|accessdate=September 3, 2015}} and B in 2014{{cite web|last1=Kaeding|first1=Nicole|last2=Edwards|first2=Chris|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://object.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/pubs/pdf/fprc-on-americas-governors_1.pdf|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors 2014|date=October 2, 2014|accessdate=September 3, 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Kaeding|first1=Nicole|last2=Edwards|first2=Chris|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|url=http://www.cato.org/publications/white-paper/fiscal-policy-report-card-americas-governors-2014|title=Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors 2014|date=October 2, 2014|accessdate=September 3, 2015}} from the [[Cato Institute]], a [[Libertarianism in the United States|libertarian]] think tank, in their biennial Fiscal Policy Report Card on America's Governors. ===Healthcare=== [[File:Texas Governor Rick Perry speaking at the Houston Technology Center in 2010.jpg|left|thumb|Governor Perry speaking at the [[Houston Technology Center]] in 2010]] As governor, Perry was an opponent of federal health-care reform proposals and of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]], describing the latter as "socialism on American soil".{{cite news|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=G.O.P. Candidates' Stances on Health Care Mask Their Records as Governors|first=Kevin|last=Sack|accessdate=September 13, 2016|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/04/us/politics/04governors.html}} His focus in Texas was on [[tort reform]], signing a bill in 2003 that restricted non-economic damages in [[medical malpractice]] judgments.{{cite news|last=Blumenthal|first=Ralph|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/15/us/malpractice-suits-capped-at-750000-in-texas-vote.html|title=Malpractice Suits Capped at $750,000 in Texas Vote|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=September 13, 2016}} Perry touted this approach in his presidential campaign, although independent analysts have concluded that it has failed to increase the supply of physicians or limit health-care costs in Texas.{{cite web|publisher=[[Social Science Research Network]]|author1=Paik, Myungho|author2=Black, Bernard S.|author3=Hyman, David A.|author4=Silver, Charles M.|title=Will Tort Reform Bend the Cost Curve? Evidence from Texas|ssrn=1635882|date=July 16, 2010}}{{dead link|date=February 2017}} During Perry's governorship, Texas rose from second to first among states with the highest proportion of uninsured residents at 26%, and had the lowest level of access to [[Prenatal care in the United States|prenatal care in the U.S.]] Perry and the state legislature cut [[Medicaid]] spending.{{cite news|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|title=Texas healthcare system withering under Gov. Perry|first=Noam|last=Levey|date=September 8, 2011|accessdate=September 13, 2016|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/sep/08/nation/la-na-perry-healthcare-20110908}} The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' wrote that under Perry, "working Texans increasingly have been priced out of private healthcare while the state's safety net has withered." Perry's office said that Texas represents a model private-sector approach to health-care. His spokeswoman stated that "Texas does provide an adequate safety net to those truly in need... and many individuals simply choose not to purchase healthcare coverage." Perry is anti-abortion and has signed bills with rules or restrictions for [[abortion]] procedures and funding for them.{{cite web |url=http://www.lifenews.com/2011/07/26/rick-perry-gets-a-grade-on-abortion-from-texas-pro-life-groups|title=Rick Perry Gets A Grade on Abortion From Texas Pro-Life Groups|publisher=LifeNews.com|date=June 10, 2011|accessdate=August 7, 2011}} In December 2011, Perry said he had undergone a "transformation" and now opposed all abortions, including in cases of rape and incest. The next day he clarified that he would allow an exception for abortions that would save a mother's life.Saenz, Arlette. [http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2011/12/rick-perry-modified-abortion-stand-again-mothers-life-only-exception/ "Rick Perry Clarifies Abortion Stand, Mother's Life Only Exception"]. ABC News, December 28, 2011.Philpott, Ben. [http://www.kutnews.org/post/rick-perry-pivots-abortion "Rick Perry Pivots on Abortion"], KUTNews.org, December 27, 2011. In February 2007, Perry issued an [[Executive order (United States)|executive order]] mandating that Texas girls receive the [[HPV vaccine]], which protects against some strains of the [[human papilloma virus]], a contributing factor to some forms of [[cervical cancer]].Carney, Timothy (June 21, 2011) [http://washingtonexaminer.com/blogs/beltway-confidential/2011/06/rick-perrys-mixed-record-regulatory-robbery "Rick Perry's mixed record on regulatory robbery"]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''[[The Washington Examiner]]'' Following the move, news outlets reported various apparent financial connections between Perry and the vaccine's manufacturer, [[Merck & Co.|Merck]].{{cite news|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/content/region/legislature/stories/02/22/22perry.html |title=Perry's staff discussed vaccine on day Merck donated to campaign |last=Peterson |first=Liz Austin |agency=Associated Press |work=[[Austin American-Statesman]] |date=February 22, 2007 |accessdate=August 7, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716133807/http://www.statesman.com/news/content/region/legislature/stories/02/22/22perry.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 }} Merck's [[political action committee]] has contributed $28,500 since 2001 to Perry's campaigns.Mason, Melanie. [http://www.latimes.com/news/politics/la-pn-perry-merck-campaign-cash-20110913,0,3068787.story?track=lat-pick "Rick Perry understated drug company campaign cash"]. ''Los Angeles Times'', September 13, 2011. The order was criticized by some parents and [[social conservatives]], and a lawsuit was filed later that month.{{cite news|url=http://newsmax.com/archives/articles/2007/2/25/111903.shtml |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120714020634/http://newsmax.com/archives/articles/2007/2/25/111903.shtml |archive-date=July 14, 2012 |title=Texas Families Seek to Block Gov's Order |agency=Associated Press |publisher=[[Newsmax Media]] |date=February 25, 2007 |accessdate=August 7, 2011 |deadurl=yes }} In May 2007, the Texas Legislature passed a bill undoing the order; Perry did not veto the bill, saying the veto would have been overruled, but blamed lawmakers who supported the bill for the deaths of future Texan cervical cancer victims.{{cite news|first=Corrie |last=MacLaggan |url=http://www.statesman.com/news/content/region/legislature/stories/05/09/9hpv.html |title=Perry lets HPV bill go into law |work=[[Austin American-Statesman]] |date=May 9, 2007 |accessdate=August 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716133814/http://www.statesman.com/news/content/region/legislature/stories/05/09/9hpv.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 }} On July 1, 2011, Perry both had adult stem cell surgery in Houston and started "laying the groundwork" for the commercialization of the adult stem cell industry in Texas.{{cite news |first=Emily |last=Ramshaw |url=http://www.texastribune.org/texas-people/rick-perry/perry-allies-lay-groundwork-tx-stem-cell-industry/ |title=Perry, Allies Lay Groundwork for TX Stem Cell Industry |work=[[The Texas Tribune]] |date=August 4, 2011 |accessdate=March 6, 2012}}{{cite news |first=Sarah |last=Maslin Nir |url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/08/04/rick-perry-has-stem-cell-procedure-then-works-to-bring-it-to-texas/ |title=Rick Perry Has Stem Cell Procedure, Then Works to Bring it to Texas |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 4, 2011 |accessdate=March 6, 2012}} ===Religion=== [[File:Rick Perry by Gage Skidmore 9.jpg|right|thumb|Governor Perry speaking at the 2014 [[Conservative Political Action Conference]] in Maryland]] Perry grew up in the [[United Methodist Church]]. He and his family were members of Tarrytown United Methodist Church in Austin until 2010, when they began attending Lake Hills Church,{{cite web |url=http://lhc.org|title=Lake Hills Church|date=|work=lhc.org|accessdate=September 13, 2015}} a non-denominational evangelical [[megachurch]] in western Travis County. Perry told the ''Austin American-Statesman'' that he began attending Lake Hills because it was close to the rental home where he and his wife lived while the Governor's Mansion was being renovated.{{cite news|last=Joshunda Sanders|first=Jason Embry|title=Candidates attending more than one church|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/texas-politics/governors_race/candidates-mirror-population-in-attending-more-than-one-1009306.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101106024905/http://www.statesman.com/news/texas-politics/governors_race/candidates-mirror-population-in-attending-more-than-one-1009306.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=November 6, 2010|newspaper=[[Austin American-Statesman]]|accessdate=August 20, 2011|df=mdy-all}} In 2006, Perry stated that he believes in the [[Biblical inerrancy|inerrancy of the Bible]] and that those who do not accept [[Jesus]] as their Savior will go to hell. A couple of days later, he clarified, "I don't know that there's any human being that has the ability to interpret what God and his final decision-making is going to be."{{cite news|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/dn/latestnews/stories/110606dnTSWperry.351c57c.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061119030904/http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/dn/latestnews/stories/110606dnTSWperry.351c57c.html|archivedate=November 19, 2006|last=Hoppe|first=Christy|title=Perry believes non-Christians doomed|work=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|date=November 6, 2006|accessdate=September 1, 2011}} In his 2008 book ''On My Honor'', Perry expressed his views on the [[Establishment Clause]] and the [[Free Exercise Clause]] of the U.S. Constitution. "Let's be clear: I don't believe government, which taxes people regardless of their faith, should espouse a specific faith. I also don't think we should allow a small minority of [[atheist]]s to sanitize our civil dialogue of religious references."{{cite book| last= Perry|first= Rick|title=On My Honor|year=2008|publisher=Stroud & Hall Publishers|location=Macon, GA|isbn=0-9796462-2-7|page=88}} In June 2011, Perry proclaimed August 6 as a Day of Prayer and [[Fasting]], inviting other governors to join him in a prayer meeting hosted by the [[American Family Association]] in Houston.{{cite web|last=Perry|first=Rick|url=http://governor.state.tx.us/news/proclamation/16247|title=Gov. Perry Declares August 6th a Day of Prayer|publisher=Office of the Governor|date=June 6, 2011|accessdate=June 29, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614162736/http://governor.state.tx.us/news/proclamation/16247/|archivedate=June 14, 2011|df=mdy-all}}Bacon, Perry, Jr.; Henderson, Nia-Malika (August 5, 2011). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/texas-gov-rick-perry-to-host-major-prayer-event-in-houston/2011/08/04/gIQAilogwI_story.html "Texas Gov. Rick Perry to host major prayer event in Houston"]. ''[[The Washington Post]]''. The event was criticized as going beyond prayer and fasting to include launching Perry's presidential campaign.{{Cite news | last = Fikac| first = Peggy| title = Email on voting prompts questions about Perry prayer event| newspaper = [[Houston Chronicle]]| date = August 19, 2011| url = http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/Email-on-voting-prompts-questions-about-Perry-2132729.php| accessdate = August 20, 2011}} Perry has called himself "a firm believer in [[intelligent design]] as a matter of faith and intellect", and has expressed support for its teaching alongside [[evolution]] in Texas schools, but has also said that "educators and local school officials, not the governor, should determine science curriculum".{{cite news |url=http://www.gosanangelo.com/news/2010/sep/11/this-series-examines-important-issues-to-texans/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100916041148/http://www.gosanangelo.com/news/2010/sep/11/this-series-examines-important-issues-to-texans/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 16, 2010 |title=2010 The Vote: K-12 Education |work=[[San Angelo Standard-Times]] |date=September 11, 2010 |accessdate=August 18, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} ===Education=== In 2005, Perry said he would not "approve an education budget that shortchanges teacher salary increases, textbooks, education technology, and education reforms. And I cannot let $2 billion sit in some bank account when it can go directly to the classroom".{{cite web|url=http://governor.state.tx.us/news/press-release/3589|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820055259/http://governor.state.tx.us/news/press-release/3589/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=August 20, 2010|title=Press Release: Gov. Perry Says Legislators Must Come Back, Get School Funding Right|publisher=Office of the Governor |accessdate=August 18, 2011}} Following a second rejection of Perry's bill, Perry asked [[John Sharp (Texas politician)|John Sharp]] to head a task force charged with preparing a bipartisan education plan, which was subsequently adopted.{{cite web|url=http://www.capitol.state.tx.us/hjrnl/792/html/79c2day03final.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051130095557/http://www.capitol.state.tx.us/hjrnl/792/html/79c2day03final.htm|archivedate=November 30, 2005|title=Proceedings: Third Day – Tuesday, July 26, 2005}}{{cite web|url=http://www.governor.state.tx.us/priorities/tax_reform/TTRC_report/files/TTRC_report.pdf|title=Gov. Perry's Principles For A Stronger Texas|publisher=Office of the Governor|accessdate=August 7, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820122527/http://governor.state.tx.us/priorities/tax_reform/TTRC_report/files/TTRC_report.pdf|archivedate=August 20, 2011|df=mdy-all}} In 2001, Perry expressed his pride in the enactment of the statute extending in-state tuition to [[undocumented immigrants]] who meet Texas' residency requirements. It also required the undocumented students to pledge to apply for permanent residency or citizenship if this became a possibility for them.{{cite web|last=Perry|first=Rick|title=Gov. Rick Perry's Remarks to the Border Summit|publisher=Office of the Governor|date=August 22, 2001|url=http://governor.state.tx.us/news/speech/10688|accessdate=August 14, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819140626/http://governor.state.tx.us/news/speech/10688/|archivedate=August 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}} In September 2014, Gov. Perry stated during a debate his continuous support for the program.{{cite web|last1=Batheja|first1=Aman|title=Perry backs in-state tuition law|url=http://www.wfaa.com/story/news/politics/2014/09/21/rick-perry-texas-tribune-festival-tuition/16013709|accessdate=September 22, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006175838/http://www.wfaa.com/story/news/politics/2014/09/21/rick-perry-texas-tribune-festival-tuition/16013709/|archive-date=October 6, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ===LGBT rights=== [[File:Rick Perry by Gage Skidmore 10.jpg|left|thumb|Perry speaking at the 2015 [[Conservative Political Action Conference]] in National Harbor, Maryland]] In 2002, Perry described the Texas same-sex [[sodomy law|anti-sodomy law]] as "appropriate".{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/2002_3605756/perry-calls-sodomy-law-appropriate.html|title=Perry calls sodomy law 'appropriate{{'-}}|work=[[Houston Chronicle]]|agency=Associated Press|date=December 4, 2002|accessdate=August 19, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120202221217/http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/2002_3605756/perry-calls-sodomy-law-appropriate.html|archivedate=February 2, 2012|df=mdy-all}} The following year, the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] struck down the statute in ''[[Lawrence v. Texas]]'', determining that it violated the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution]]. In his 2010 book, Perry referenced the ''Lawrence'' decision, writing "Texans have a different view of the world than do the nine oligarchs in robes."Arlette Saenz, [http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2011/12/perry-draws-blank-on-landmark-texas-anti-sodomy-supreme-court-case/ Perry Draws Blank on Landmark Texas Anti-Sodomy Supreme Court Case], ABC News, December 29, 2011. In 2011, Perry admitted that he did not know about the ''Lawrence'' decision; when told that the Supreme Court case had struck down Texas's anti-sodomy law, Perry said: "I'm not taking the [[bar exam]] ... I don't know what a lot of legal cases involve ... [M]y position on traditional marriage is clear ... I don't need a federal law case to explain it to me." Perry supported [[Texas Proposition 2 (2005)|Texas Proposition 2 in 2005]], a ballot proposition that [[List of former U.S. state constitutional amendments banning same-sex unions by type|amended the Texas constitution by defining marriage]] as "only a union between a man and a woman" and prohibiting the state from creating or recognizing "any legal status identical or similar to marriage" (such as [[civil union]]s).{{Cite news|title=Same-sex marriage ban wins OK|url=http://www.chron.com/default/article/Same-sex-marriage-ban-wins-OK-1933429.php|date=November 8, 2005|first=Janet|last=Elliott|work=[[Houston Chronicle]]|accessdate=August 29, 2011}} In 2011, after [[Marriage Equality Act (New York)|New York legalized same-sex marriage]], Perry stated that it was their right to do so under the principle of [[states' rights]] in the [[Tenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Tenth Amendment]].{{cite news|url=http://caucuses.desmoinesregister.com/2011/07/23/perry-defends-gay-marriage-as-a-states-choice-santorum-takes-a-swipe/|title=Perry defends gay marriage as states' choice; Santorum takes a swipe|first=Jennifer|last=Jacobs|work=[[The Des Moines Register]]|date=July 23, 2011|accessdate=August 19, 2011}} A spokesman later reiterated Perry's support for a [[Federal Marriage Amendment|federal constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage]], saying that position was not inconsistent, since an amendment would require ratification by three-fourths of the states.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jul/28/news/la-pn-perry-gay-marriage-20110728|title=Rick Perry contorts over same-sex marriage|first=Mark Z.|last=Barabak|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 28, 2011|accessdate=August 19, 2011}} After the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in ''[[Obergefell v. Hodges]]'' in 2015 that the fundamental right to marry is guaranteed to same-sex couples by the Constitution, Perry condemned the decision, saying: "I'm a firm believer in traditional marriage, and I also believe the 10th Amendment leaves it to each state to decide this issue."Jennifer Rubin, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/right-turn/wp/2015/06/26/the-gop-contenders-react-to-the-same-sex-marriage-decision/ The GOP contenders react to the same-sex marriage decision], ''The Washington Post'', June 26, 2015. In his first book, ''On My Honor'', published in 2008, Perry drew a parallel between [[homosexuality]] and alcoholism, writing that he is "no expert on the 'nature versus nurture' debate" but that gays should simply choose abstinence.{{Cite news|url=http://swampland.time.com/2011/08/24/perry-compared-homosexuality-to-alcoholism-in-2008-book|title=Perry Compared Homosexuality to Alcoholism in 2008 Book|date=August 24, 2011|first=Mark|last=Benjamin|work=Time|accessdate=October 21, 2011}} During the 2012 presidential campaign, he criticized the repeal of the "[[don't ask, don't tell]]" policy for the U.S. military.{{Cite news|title=Rick Perry's Anti-Gay Iowa Ad Divides His Top Staff|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/12/08/rick-perry-anti-gay-iowa-ad-divides-top-staff_n_1136587.html|date=December 8, 2011|first=Sam|last=Stein|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=February 15, 2012}} Perry said using foreign aid as a policy tool against foreign countries that violate the human rights of homosexuals was "not in America's interests" and was part of a "war on traditional American values".{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2011/12/rick-perry-says-human-rights-for-gays-not-in-americas-interests|title=Rick Perry Says Human Rights for Gays 'Not in America's Interests'|publisher=ABC News|date=December 6, 2011|accessdate=February 22, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301081125/http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/politics/2011/12/rick-perry-says-human-rights-for-gays-not-in-americas-interests/|archivedate=March 1, 2014|df=mdy-all}} Perry, an Eagle Scout, has called on the [[Boy Scouts of America|Boy Scouts]] to continue their ban on homosexuality and blamed America for not living up to the ideals of the Scouts.Associated Press, [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/03/us/rick-perry-opposes-opening-boy-scouts-to-gays.html Perry Fights Letting Gays in Boy Scouts], nytimes.com, February 2, 2013. ===Crime=== Perry's campaigns for lieutenant governor and governor focused on a [[Law and order (politics)|tough stance on crime]]. He has supported [[block grant]]s for crime programs.{{cite web|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/Notebook/Note_01-NGA10.htm|title=Public Notes on 01-NGA10|publisher=[[On The Issues]]|date=September 14, 2001|accessdate=August 18, 2011}} Jeff L. Blackburn, chief counsel of the [[Innocence Project of Texas]], said of Perry that "He has done more good than any other governor we've ever had ... unless, of course, it involves the death penalty. On the [[Rick Perry#Death penalty|death penalty]], Rick Perry has a profound mental block."Sontag, Deborah (October 30, 2011). [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/31/us/politics/rick-perry-displays-varied-stance-toward-crime.html "Perry Displays Varied Stance Toward Crime"]. ''The New York Times''. In 2007, Perry signed a law ending automatic arrest for [[cannabis]] possession.Yoder, Steve (November 7, 2011). [http://www.salon.com/2011/11/07/the_gop_tough_on_crime_no_more/ "The GOP, 'tough on crime' no more?"] Salon. ===Death penalty=== {{Details|Capital punishment in Texas}} Perry supports the [[death penalty]].{{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/69546/output/print|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071113100211/http://www.newsweek.com/id/69546/output/print|dead-url=yes|archive-date=November 13, 2007|title=Injection of Reflection|last=Thomas|first=Evan|first2=Martha|last2=Brant|work=[[Newsweek]]|date=November 10, 2007|accessdate=June 22, 2008|df=mdy-all}} In June 2001, he vetoed a ban on the [[death penalty|execution]] of [[Intellectual disability|mentally retarded]] inmates.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/06/18/us/ban-on-execution-of-the-retarded-is-vetoed-in-texas.html|title=Ban on Execution of the Retarded is Vetoed in Texas|last=Bonner|first=Raymond|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 18, 2001|accessdate=September 12, 2015}} In 2011, during a televised debate for presidential candidates, he said he'd "never struggled" with the question of the possible innocence of any of the 234 inmates executed to date while he was governor.{{cite news |last1=Montopoli |first1=Brian |title=Rick Perry: I don't lose sleep over Texas executions |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/rick-perry-i-dont-lose-sleep-over-texas-executions/ |accessdate=31 May 2018 |publisher=CBS News |date=7 September 2011}} Cases in which Perry has been criticized for his lack of intervention include those of [[Cameron Todd Willingham]] and Mexican nationals [[José Medellín]] and [[Humberto Leal Garcia]].{{Cite news|title=From arson to politics: Why has Texas's governorderailed a death-penalty investigation?|newspaper=[[The Economist]]|date=October 22, 2009|url=http://www.economist.com/node/14699746|accessdate=August 13, 2011}}{{cite news|last=Grann|first=David|url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2009/09/07/090907fa_fact_grann|title=Cameron Todd Willingham, Texas, and the death penalty|work=[[The New Yorker]]|date=January 7, 2009|accessdate=August 7, 2011}}{{cite web|last=Graczyk|first=Michael|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/2011/07/08/3209871/criticism-of-texas-execution-of.html|title=Criticism of Texas' execution of Mexican Humberto Leal Garcia doesn't bother Perry|work=[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]|date=July 8, 2011|accessdate=August 7, 2011}}{{dead link|date=February 2017}} Perry commuted the death sentence of [[Kenneth Foster]], who was convicted of murder despite evidence that he was only present at the scene of the crime. Foster was convicted under a Texas law that makes co-conspirators liable in certain cases of homicide. In this case, it tied Foster to the triggerman. Perry raised doubts about the law and urged the legislature to re-examine the issue. "I believe the right and just decision is to commute Foster's sentence from the death penalty to life imprisonment", Perry said in a statement at the time.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/31/us/31execute.html?_r=1&|newspaper=The New York Times|title=Governor Commutes Sentence in Texas|date=August 31, 2007}} Perry also refused to grant a stay of execution in the case of [[Cameron Todd Willingham]] even though an investigation by the [[Texas Forensic Science Commission]] determined parts of the original investigation may not have looked at all of the evidence correctly. Perry called Willingham a "monster" and later replaced the chairman of the Science Commission.{{cite news|last1=Thornton|first1=Paul|title=Cameron Todd Willingham's ghost won't stop haunting Rick Perry|url=http://www.latimes.com/opinion/opinion-la/la-ol-cameron-todd-willingham-rick-perry-execution-20140806-story.html|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=August 6, 2014|accessdate=May 20, 2015}} ===Infrastructure=== In 2002, Perry proposed the [[Trans-Texas Corridor]], a $175 billion transportation network that would include a 4,000-mile network of highways, rail, and utility lines and would be funded by private investors. Plans for the project were dropped in 2009 in favor of more incremental road projects.{{cite news|last1=Ruiz|first1=Rosanna|last2=Elliott|first2=Janet|last3=Ratcliffe|first3=R.G.|title=Trans-Texas Corridor plans dropped after public outcry|url=http://www.chron.com/neighborhood/cyfair-news/article/Trans-Texas-Corridor-plans-dropped-after-public-1745411.php|accessdate=13 June 2017|publisher=Houston Chronicle|date=January 6, 2009}}{{cite web|title=Trans-texas Corridor|url=https://www.texastribune.org/tribpedia/trans-texas-corridor/about/|publisher=Texas Tribune|accessdate=13 June 2017}} ===Gun ownership=== Perry has an A+ rating from the [[National Rifle Association]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nraila.org/News/Read/InTheNews.aspx?ID=15316|title=Rick Perry's unwavering support for gun rights could boost his presidential prospects|publisher=nraila.org|accessdate=August 14, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717021720/http://www.nraila.org/News/Read/InTheNews.aspx?ID=15316|archivedate=July 17, 2011}} He possesses a [[Concealed Carry License]] (CCL){{cite news|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/local/wily-coyote-no-match-for-governors-gun-634362.html|title='Wily' coyote no match for governor's gun|work=[[Austin American-Statesman]]|accessdate=August 14, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100501185423/http://www.statesman.com/news/local/wily-coyote-no-match-for-governors-gun-634362.html|archivedate=May 1, 2010|df=mdy-all}} and has signed a number of bills that increased CHL access.{{cite web|url=http://governor.state.tx.us/news/press-release/3598|title=Gov. Perry Signs Bills to Protect Gun Owners' Rights|publisher=Office of the Governor Rick Perry|accessdate=August 14, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820083644/http://governor.state.tx.us/news/press-release/3598/|archivedate=August 20, 2011|df=mdy-all}} ===Illegal immigration=== During a large surge in [[Illegal immigration to the United States|illegal immigration]] through the U.S. southern border in the summer of 2014, Perry criticized U.S. President [[Barack Obama]], saying that the surge was "a humanitarian crisis that he has the ability to stop."{{cite web | title=Texas Gov. Perry: Illegal Immigrant Surge a 'Humanitarian Crisis' Obama Can Stop | url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2014/07/10/texas-gov-perry-illegal-immigrant-surge-humanitarian-crisis-obama-has-power-to.html | date=July 10, 2014 | publisher=[[Fox News]] | accessdate=April 9, 2017}} On July 21, 2014, Perry announced he would send in 1,000 [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] troops to secure the border.{{cite news | last1=Fernandez | first1=Manny | last2=Shear | first2=Michael D. | title=Texas Governor Bolsters Border, and His Profile | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/22/us/perry-to-deploy-national-guard-troops-to-mexico-border.html?_r=0 | date=July 21, 2014 | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | accessdate=April 9, 2017}}{{cite web | last1=Root | first1=Jay | title=Perry Sending Guard Troops to the Border | url=https://www.texastribune.org/2014/07/21/perry-activate-1000-guard-troops/ | date=July 21, 2014 | publisher=''[[The Texas Tribune]]'' | accessdate=April 9, 2017}} Although illegal immigration levels declined over 70% after Perry deployed the National Guard, [[PolitiFact.com]] rated his claim that the decline resulted from the surge as "mostly false."{{cite web | last1=Saacks | first1=Bradley | title=Rick Perry Says 74 Percent Drop in Border Apprehensions Shows Texas Surge Worked | url=http://www.politifact.com/texas/statements/2015/jul/26/rick-perry/rick-perry-says-74-percent-drop-border-apprehensio/ | date=July 26, 2015 | publisher=[[PolitiFact.com]] | accessdate=April 9, 2017}} ===Veto controversy and exoneration=== {{main|Rick Perry veto controversy}} On August 15, 2014, Perry was [[Indictment#United States|indicted]] by a Travis County [[grand jury]].{{cite news|author=Benjy Sarlin|url=http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/rick-perry-indicted-abuse-power-grand-jury|title=Rick Perry indicted for abuse of power by grand jury|publisher=MSNBC|date=August 12, 2014|accessdate=August 17, 2014}} The first charge of the [[indictment]] was abuse of official capacity, which has since been ruled unconstitutional, for threatening to veto $7.5 million in funding for the Public Integrity Unit, a state public corruption prosecutors department. The second charge, which has also since been ruled unconstitutional, was coercion of a public servant,{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2014/08/15/texas-gov-perry-indicted-for-coercion-for-veto-threat|title=Texas Gov. Rick Perry indicted for alleged abuse of power in veto dispute|publisher=Fox News|date=October 1, 2006|accessdate=August 17, 2014}} for seeking the resignation of Travis County [[District Attorney]] [[Rosemary Lehmberg]], a Democrat,{{cite news|author=Manny Fernandez|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/16/us/gov-rick-perry-of-texas-is-indicted-over-veto-of-funds-for-das-office.html|title=Gov. Rick Perry of Texas Is Indicted on Charge of Abuse of Power|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 15, 2014|accessdate=August 20, 2014}} after she was convicted of [[drunk driving]], and incarcerated. Perry pleaded not guilty to both charges. Perry's supporters called the charges political and partisan,{{cite news|title=Texas Gov. Rick Perry is indicted|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/politics/politicsnow/la-na-pn-rick-perry-indictment-texas-20140815-story.html|newspaper=Los Angeles times|accessdate=August 16, 2014}} and several Democratic commentators, including [[David Axelrod (political consultant)|David Axelrod]], [[Matthew Yglesias]], and [[Jonathan Chait]] stated they believed the charges were either weak or unwarranted.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/texas-perry-indicted-for-coercion-for-veto-threat/2014/08/15/a7bda58a-24ce-11e4-8b10-7db129976abb_story.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140816150221/http://www.washingtonpost.com/national/texas-perry-indicted-for-coercion-for-veto-threat/2014/08/15/a7bda58a-24ce-11e4-8b10-7db129976abb_story.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=August 16, 2014|title=Perry indicted|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=August 15, 2014}}{{cite news|title=Even Liberals Think The Indictment Of Rick Perry Looks Weak|author=Colin Campbell|newspaper=Business Insider|date=August 16, 2014|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/liberals-criticize-rick-perry-indictment-2014-8#ixzz3AZ2yPug8|accessdate=August 16, 2014}} In February 2016, Perry was cleared of all charges.Dann, Carrie. "Texas Court Dismisses Second Felony Charge Against Rick Perry", [[NBC News]] (February 24, 2016). The [[Texas Court of Criminal Appeals]] ruled that courts could not limit [[veto power]] and that prosecuting Perry over his action violates "the [[separation of powers]] provision of the Texas Constitution" and infringed on Perry's [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] right to [[freedom of speech]].{{cite news|last1=Malewitz|first1=Jim|last2=Ramsey|first2=Ross|date=February 24, 2016|title=Texas Court of Criminal Appeals Dismisses Rick Perry Indictment|url=http://www.texastribune.org/2016/02/24/texas-high-court-dismisses-rick-perry-indictments|newspaper=[[Texas Tribune]]|location=[[Austin, Texas]]|accessdate=February 25, 2016}} ===Retirement as governor=== {{see also|Political positions of Rick Perry|United States presidential election, 2016}} By the end of his third full term, he had served more than 14 consecutive years in office. A University of Texas at Austin–''[[Texas Tribune]]'' poll released in June 2013, showed Perry leading potential primary challenger [[Texas Attorney General|Attorney General]] [[Greg Abbott]] by double digits, 45–19%.[http://www.texastribune.org/2013/06/17/uttt-poll-texans-favor-cruz-over-perry-president/ UT/TT Poll: Texans Favor Cruz Over Perry for President], TexasTribune.org; retrieved August 12, 2013. In February, the same poll had Perry leading by a 3-to-1 margin (49–17%) of 32 points over Abbott.[http://www.texastribune.org/2013/03/04/uttt-poll-perry-starts-ahead-abbott-2014-race UT/TT Poll: Perry Starts Ahead of Abbott in 2014 Race], TexasTribune.org; retrieved on August 12, 2013. However, Perry decided not to run for re-election to a fourth full term, announcing in front of family and supporters at the [[Holt Manufacturing Company|Holt Cat]] headquarters in [[San Antonio]] on July 8, 2013 that he would retire instead.{{cite news|url=http://abclocal.go.com/ktrk/story?section=news/state&id=9164598|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130711043937/http://abclocal.go.com/ktrk/story?section=news%2Fstate&id=9164598|dead-url=yes|archive-date=July 11, 2013|title=Texas Gov. Rick Perry announces he will not seek re-election in 2014|publisher=KTRK|date=July 8, 2013|accessdate=July 8, 2013|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news |title=Rick Perry Won't Run for Re-election|date=July 8, 2013|url=http://www.texastribune.org/2013/07/08/rick-perrys-big-decision|newspaper=[[The Texas Tribune]]|accessdate=October 11, 2014}} Perry retired with the 10th longest gubernatorial tenure in United States history at the end of his term on January 20, 2015 at {{formatnum:{{age in days|2000|12|21|2015|1|20}}}} days as well as the record of the longest serving Texas Governor.{{cite web|url=http://editions.lib.umn.edu/smartpolitics/2013/07/08/perry-will-retire-with-10th-lo|title= Perry Will Retire with 10th Longest Gubernatorial Tenure in US History |work=Smart Politics|first=Eric|last=Ostermeier|date=July 8, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://editions.lib.umn.edu/smartpolitics/2015/01/20/perry-exits-10-in-all-time-gub|title=Perry Exits #10 in All-Time Gubernatorial Tenure|work=Smart Politics|first=Eric|last=Ostermeier|date=January 20, 2015}} ==2012 presidential campaign== {{main|Rick Perry presidential campaign, 2012}} [[File:RickPerry Iowa Fair.jpg|thumb|Perry campaigning at the Iowa State Fair, August 14, 2011]] Perry was considered as a potential candidate since as early as the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 presidential election]], initially denying he was interested in the office but later becoming more open-minded.
