{{Infobox person | name = | birth_name = Steven Neil Posner | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = January 11, 1943 | birth_place = [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2010|11|29|1943|1|11}} | death_place = [[Biscayne Bay]], [[Florida]] | education = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = Businessman | spouse = Susan Goldman | partner = | children = Kelly Posner Gerstenhaber
Sean Posner
Jarrett Posner | parents = [[Victor Posner]] | relatives = [[Tracy Posner]] (Paternal Half-Sister) }} '''Steven Neil Posner''' (pronounced POZ-ner; January 11, 1943 – November 29, 2010) was an American [[corporate raid]]er who worked together on a number of major [[Takeover#Hostile takeovers|hostile takeovers]] with his father, [[Victor Posner]], though the two would later have a falling out that resulted in a series of acrimonious lawsuits. A 1989 corporate takeover staged by the Posners led to fraud convictions for [[Ivan Boesky]] and [[Michael Milken]] levied by the [[United States Securities and Exchange Commission]] for their role in improperly assisting the Posners in the attempted deal.{{citation needed|date=December 2010}} ==Biography== Posner was born on January 11, 1943, in [[Baltimore]] and joined his father's business acquiring and managing corporations. In 1988, the SEC charged that the Posners had colluded with Ivan Boesky and Michael Milken to conceal their stock purchases during the 1984 Posner-led takeover of the [[Fischbach Corporation]]. While Boesky and Milken agreed to plead guilty to felony counts in relation to their activities in the Fischbach case, the Posners were required to relinquish the financial gains they had made in the deal and to relinquish ownership stakes they held in other companies.Hevesi, Dennis. [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/01/business/01posner.html "Steven Posner, 67, Former Corporate Raider, Dies"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', November 30, 2010. Accessed December 1, 2010. Posner sued his father in 1995, claiming that the senior Posner had overpaid himself while operating a firm in which his son had an ownership stake. The settlement amount was determined based on the result of a gold coin flipped in front of the judge.via [[Associated Press]]. [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/afterword/2010/11/steven-posner-real-estate-tycoon-dies-at-67.html "Steven Posner, real estate tycoon, dies at 67"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', November 30, 2010. Accessed December 6, 2010. After his father's death in 2002, Steven took over the real estate investments that his father had controlled. ==Personal life== In 1966, he married Susan Goldman; they had three children: Kelly Posner Gerstenhaber (married to David Gerstenhaber, son of [[Murray Gerstenhaber]]); Sean Posner; and Jarrett Posner{{Cite web|last=Hevesi |first=Dennis |authorlink= |title=Steven Posner, 67, Former Corporate Raider |publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=December 2, 2010 |url=https://archive.nytimes.com/query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage-9F03EEDA1631F931A35751C1A9669D8B63.html |accessdate=March 15, 2018}} (married to Elana Waksal, daughter of [[Samuel D. Waksal]]).{{Cite web|last=Kranes |first=Marsha |authorlink= |title=Something in the Heir – Scandals Link Power Pair|publisher=[[New York Post]]|date=June 13, 2002|url=https://nypost.com/2002/06/13/something-in-the-heir-scandals-link-power-pair/|accessdate=March 15, 2018}} A resident of [[Miami]], Posner died at the age of 67 on November 29, 2010, as a result of an accident in which his boat collided with another boat, killing him and another passenger and leaving a third passenger of the boat severely injured. The crash was described as the result of a mechanical failure in one of the boats as they were traveling next to each other in [[Biscayne Bay]].Litz, Steve. [http://www.nbcmiami.com/news/local-beat/expert-says-mechanical-failure-not-racing-led-to-boat-crash-111079704.html "Mechanical Failure, Not Racing, Led to Boat Crash: ExpertBoth vessels were capable of speeds of about 100 mph"], [[WTVJ|NBC Miami]], November 30, 2010. Accessed December 1, 2010. He was survived by his wife, as well as by a daughter, two sons and five grandchildren. Family member, Jillian Posner, has taken over Steven's charity roles and was recently awarded a Proclamation from the City of Miami Beach for her fluent work in philanthropy. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Posner, Steven}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in Florida]] [[Category:American financiers]] [[Category:American people of Russian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Corporate raiders]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Baltimore]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Miami]] [[Category:Private equity and venture capital investors]] [[Category:Boating accident deaths]]

{{infobox military person |image = Tang Xiangming.jpg |birth_date = 1885 |birth_place = [[Hubei]] Province, {{flagicon|Qing Dynasty}}[[Qing Empire]] |death_date = 1975 |death_place = [[Beijing]], {{PRC}} |allegiance = [[Tongmenghui]] |battles = {{plainlist| *[[Xinhai Revolution]] *:[[Wuchang Uprising]] }} }} '''Tang Xiangming''' ({{zh|汤芗铭}}) (1885–1975) was a Chinese naval officer. Tang studied Naval warfare in [[France]] and the [[United Kingdom]]. In 1905, he joined the Chinese United League ([[Tongmenghui]]). In 1911, during the Wuchang Uprising, Tang, under the command of Admiral [[Sa Zhenbing]], sailed to [[Hankou]] as part of the Qing Navy's assistance to the Qing Army operations in the area. In December 1915, he supported [[Yuan Shikai]]'s creation of the [[Empire of China (1915-16)]]. After Yuan's death, he supported the [[Zhili clique]] until their defeat by the [[Fengtian clique]] in the [[Second Zhili-Fengtian War]] in 1924. In 1930, he supported Shanxi warlord [[Yan Xishan]] in opposing [[Chiang Kai-shek]]. In 1933, he became a member of the [[China Democratic Socialist Party]]. During the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]], he went to [[Chongqing]]. After the end of the [[Chinese Civil War]], he stayed on the mainland and died in Beijing at the age of 90. [[File:Tang Xiangming2.jpg|thumb|left|150px|年轻时着Navy军服的Tang Xiangming]] == References == {{commonscat|Tang Xiangming}}

{{Infobox person |name = Pascal Uzoma Dozie |image = |caption = |birth_place = [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1969|11|02|df=yes}} |education = {{flatlist| *[[Master of Business Administration]] (Imperial College) *[[Bachelor of Science]] ([[University of Reading]]) *[[Master of Science]] ([[University College London]]) }} |occupation = {{flatlist| *[[Chief Executive Officer]] [[Diamond Bank]] *[[Group Managing Director]] *[[Executive Director]] *'''Member of Board Credit Committee''' }} |years_active = 2005 — present |nationality = [[Nigerian]] |citizenship = [[Nigeria]] |residence = |known_for = Banking |networth = |home_town = |title = |website = }}
'''Uzoma Dozie''' (born November 2, 1969) is a Nigerian banker, investor, economist and also advocate of technology.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ogun State varsity commissions ICT Centre|url=http://www.news24.com.ng/National/News/Ogun-State-varsity-commissions-ICT-Centre-20150312|publisher=Okoro Chinedu|accessdate=15 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The CEO as Brand Ambassador|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/the-ceo-as-brand-ambassador/203306/|accessdate=5 March 2012}}</ref> Uzoma is the Group Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer of [[Diamond Bank]] Plc, a leading retail financial institution in Nigeria and also served as Executive Director of Corporate Banking and Executive Director of Regional Business Lagos & West Regions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Uzoma Dozie emerges new Diamond Bank CEO|url=http://dailyindependentnig.com/2014/10/uzoma-dozie-emerges-new-diamond-bank-ceo/|publisher=Bamidele Ogunwusi|accessdate=27 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Uzoma Dozie assumes as Diamond Bank’s chief Nov 1|url=http://www.tribune.com.ng/news/news-headlines/item/19780-uzoma-dozie-assumes-as-diamond-bank-s-chief-nov-1/19780-uzoma-dozie-assumes-as-diamond-bank-s-chief-nov-1|publisher=Sulaimon Olanrewaju - tribune.com.ng|accessdate=27 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Diamond Bank appoints Uzoma as CEO|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2014/10/diamond-bank-appoints-uzoma-ceo-%E2%80%A2otti-resigns/|publisher=Babajide Komolafe - vanguardngr.com|accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref>
==Career== Uzoma Dozie became the new GMD and Bank CEO after [[Alex Otti]] took voluntary retirement, On October 24, 2014.<ref>http://businessdayonline.com/2014/10/alex-otti-resigns-as-diamond-bank-md/#.VRfmMUJSbvw</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Alex Otti Quits Diamond Bank As CEO, Uzoma Dozie Takes Over|url=http://www.nigeriancurrent.com/ck84-business/alex-otti-quits-diamond-bank-as-ceo-uzoma-dozie-takes-over|publisher=Patrick Aigbokhan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=UZOMA DOZIE STEPS INTO THE HELM OF AFFAIRS AS DIAMOND BANK'S CHIEF|url=http://www.diamondbank.com/index.php/63-news/press-releases/602-uzoma-dozie-steps-into-the-helm-of-affairs-as-diamond-bank-s-chief|publisher=diamondbank.com}}</ref> In 2015, Uzoma made a public appearance in a Diamond Bank Plc official television commercial featuring the Diamond Bank Mobile App.<ref>{{cite web|title=The CEO as Brand Ambassador|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/the-ceo-as-brand-ambassador/203306/|accessdate=5 March 2012}}</ref>
==Early life and education==
Uzoma was born in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] to '''Pascal G. Dozie''', the founder of [[Diamond Bank]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Executive Profile Pascal G. Dozie Co-Founder, Partner, and Non-Executive Partner, African Capital Alliance |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=24308780&privcapId=25875604|publisher=bloomberg}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

revision.comment: "secretary of the Central Comitee" is not the same thing that "member of the Poliburo"
revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder |image =Yekaterina Furtseva 1964b.jpg |caption = Yekaterina Furtseva in 1964 |name = Yekaterina Furtseva
Екатерина Фурцева |office = [[Ministry of Culture (Soviet Union)|Minister of Culture]] |term_start = 4 May 1960 |term_end = 24 October 1974 |premier = [[Nikita Khrushchev]]
[[Alexei Kosygin]] |predecessor = [[Nikolai Mikhailov]] |successor = [[Pyotr Demichev]] |office1 = First Secretary of the [[Moscow City Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Moscow City Party Committee]] |term_start1 = 17 November 1954 |term_end1 = 30 June 1957 |predecessor1 = [[Ivan Kapitonov]] |successor1 = [[Vladimir Ustinov (politician)|Vladimir Ustinov]] |office3 = Full member of the [[20th Presidium of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|20th]] [[Presidium of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Presidium]] |term_start3 = 29 June 1957 |term_end3 = 31 October 1961 |office4 = Candidate member of the [[20th Presidium of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|20th]] [[Presidium of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Presidium]] |term_start4 = 27 February 1956 |term_end4 = 29 June 1957 |office5 = Member of the [[20th Secretariat of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|20th]] [[Secretariat of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Secretariat]] |term_start5 = 27 February 1956 |term_end5 = 4 May 1960 |birth_date = {{birth date|1910|11|24|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Vyshny Volochyok]], [[Tver Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1974|10|24|1910|11|24|df=y}} |death_place = [[Moscow]], [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Russian SFSR]], [[Soviet Union]] |nationality = [[Soviet people|Soviet]] |ethnicity = [[Russians|Russian]] |party = [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] |profession = [[Civil servant]] }} '''Yekaterina Alexeyevna Furtseva''' ({{lang-ru|Екатерина Алексеевна Фурцева}}; 7 December 1910 – 24 October 1974) was probably the most influential woman in [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] politics and the second woman to be admitted as secretary of the [[Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] (the first being [[Yelena Stasova]], member of the [[7th Bureau and the 7th Secretariat of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|7th Bureau]]). Furtseva was born in [[Vyshny Volochyok]]. Until the 1940s, she worked as an ordinary weaver at one of [[Moscow]]'s textile factories. She had been a minor party worker in [[Kursk]] and the [[Crimea]], and was called to Moscow and sent to the Institute of Chemical Technology from where she graduated in 1941 as a chemical engineer.[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,861981-1,00.html O, Ekaterina.] [[Time magazine|Time]], March 12, 1956. Accessed 4 January 2009. Furtseva's party career started under [[Joseph Stalin]]. Gradually, she became active in [[Komsomol]] affairs and rose to the position of Secretary of the [[Moscow]] City Council in 1950. She gave a speech at the [[19th Congress of the CPSU]] in 1952, the last party congress of the Stalin era, where she was also elected a candidate member of the [[Central Committee of the CPSU]]. Under [[Nikita Khrushchev]], who sympathized with her, Furtseva was the first secretary of Moscow Committee of the CPSU from 1954 to 1957. In 1952, Furtseva attacked the leading filmstar, [[Boris Babochkin]], who was famous since starring as [[Vasily Chapayev]]. This time Furtseva saw the actor starring in a stageplay, and was enraged by Babochkin's satirical portrayal of the Soviet communist leadership. Her angry article in the Soviet newspaper [[Pravda]] called for censorship of Babochkin, while Furtseva furthered her career in the Soviet elite. Then Furtseva personally ordered that all film studios and drama companies of the USSR should refuse Babochkin any jobs, keeping him [[unemployed]].[http://www.sovsekretno.ru/magazines/article/1135 Совершенно СЕКРЕТНО – Чапаем заклейменный]. Sovsekretno.ru. Retrieved on 2012-08-05. In 1956 she was appointed a Secretary of the [[Central Committee]] and was elected a candidate member of Politburo. She became the first woman to join the Politburo the next year. In this capacity, she sided with Khrushchev in [[de-Stalinization]] during the [[Khrushchev's Thaw]], and secured the downfall of [[Vyacheslav Molotov]], [[Georgy Malenkov]], and [[Lazar Kaganovich]] when they conspired to depose her patron. During that time she fell in love with [[Nikolay Firyubin]], the Soviet ambassador in [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]].[http://gazeta.aif.ru/online/superstar/104/36_01 Любимые мужчины Екатерины Фурцевой, Аргументы и факты № 02 (104]. Gazeta.aif.ru (30 January 2007). Retrieved on 2012-08-05. Furtseva scandalized the Soviet elite by her weekend trips abroad in order to meet her lover. As he married her and rose to become the Deputy Foreign Minister, they settled in Moscow, and their relations cooled down somewhat. During the following 14 years, remembered as the Age of Furtseva, she exerted immense influence on Soviet culture, both repressive and beneficent. As she became increasingly interested in manipulating theatre and cinema, many remarkable actors and directors tried to secure her friendship in order to further their own careers. According to the most intimate of her friends (such as the singer [[Lyudmila Zykina]]), she also became addicted to alcohol. On 19 June 1974, ''[[Pravda]]'' revealed that she had failed to be re-elected to the Supreme Soviet. Two months previous she had been disciplined by the Party for extravagance and fined 40,000 rubles."Taste for luxury downs Soviet leader," ''[[Deseret News]]'', 19 June 1974, p. A1 She died in [[Moscow]] a few months later, officially of heart failure. Yet there were rumors that she was implicated in illegal commercial dealings and, wishing to preclude the impending scandal and disgrace, committed suicide.Vladimir Shlapentokh, and Joshau Woods. [https://books.google.com/books?id=yRfcAAAAIAAJ&dq=%22Ekaterina+Furtseva%22+suicide&ei=NRdgSfb1Co74MMWioNsH ''Contemporary Russia as a Feudal Society: A New Perspective on the Post-Soviet Era''.] [[Palgrave Macmillan]], 2007. {{ISBN|978-0-230-60096-6}}; p. 59 Furtseva is buried at the [[Novodevichye Cemetery]].[http://novodevichye.com/furtseva/ Furtseva's grave]. novodevichye.com == References == {{Commons category}} {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Furtseva, Yekaterina Alexeyevna}} [[Category:1910 births]] [[Category:1974 deaths]] [[Category:Burials at Novodevichy Cemetery]] [[Category:People from Vyshny Volochyok]] [[Category:Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union members]] [[Category:People's Commissars and Ministers of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Politburo of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union members]] [[Category:Soviet women in politics]] [[Category:20th-century women politicians]] [[Category:Textile workers]] [[Category:Russian communists]]
